16Then Joab blew the trumpet [to signal the end of the combat], and the men returned from pursuing Israel, for Joab held them back. 17They took [down the body of] Absalom and threw him into a deep pit in the forest and set up a huge mound of stones over him. Then all Israel fled, everyone to his own tent. 18Now Absalom in his lifetime had taken and set up for himself a memorial pillar which is in the King’s Valley, for he said, “I have no son to keep my name in remembrance.” He named the memorial pillar after himself, and to this day it is called Absalom’s Monument.

David Is Grief-stricken 19Then Ahimaaz the son of Zadok, said, “Let me run and bring the king news that the LORD has vindicated him by rescuing him from [the power of] his enemies.” 20But Joab told him, “You are not the man to carry news [to King David] today, but you shall carry news another day. On this day you shall carry no news, because the king’s son is dead.” 21Then Joab said to the Cushite (Ethiopian), “Go, tell the king what you have seen.” And the Cushite bowed to Joab and ran. 22Then Ahimaaz the son of Zadok said again to Joab, “But whatever happens, please let me also run after the Cushite.” Joab said, “Why should you run, my son, seeing you will have no messenger’s reward for going [because you have only bad news]?” 23“But whatever happens, Let me run.” So Joab said to him, “Run.” Then Ahimaaz ran by the way of the plain [of the Jordan River] and outran the Cushite.

24Now David was sitting between the two gates; and the lookout went up to the roof of the gate by the wall, and when he raised his eyes and looked, he saw a man running alone. 25The lookout called down and told the king. The king said, “If he is alone, he has good news to tell.” And he came nearer and nearer. 26Then the lookout saw another man running, and he called to the gatekeeper and said, “Look, another man running alone.” The king said, “He also is bringing good news.” 27The lookout said, “I think the man in front runs like Ahimaaz the son of Zadok.” The king said, “He is a good man and is coming with good news.”

28And Ahimaaz called out and said to the king, “All is well.” And he bowed before the king with his face to the ground and said, “Blessed be the LORD your God, who has handed over the men who lifted up their hands [to fight] against my lord the king.” 29The king asked, “Is the young man Absalom safe?” Ahimaaz answered, “When Joab sent the king’s servant, and your servant, I saw a great turmoil, but I do not know what it was about.” 30The king told him, “Step aside; stand here.” And he stepped aside and stood still.

31Behold, the Cushite (Ethiopian) arrived, and said, “Let my lord the king receive good news, for the LORD has vindicated you today by rescuing you from the hand (power) of all those who stood against you.” 32The king asked the Cushite, “Is the young man Absalom [my son] safe?” The Cushite replied, “May the enemies of my lord the king, and all those who rise against you to do evil, be [dead] like that young man is.”

33The king was deeply moved and went to the upper room over the gate and wept [in sorrow]. And this is what he said as he walked: “O my son Absalom, my son, my son Absalom! How I wish that I had died instead of you, O Absalom, my son, my son!”

2 Samuel 19
Joab Reproves David’s Lament

1It was told to Joab, “Behold, the king is weeping and mourning for Absalom.” 2So the victory on that day was turned into mourning for all the people, for the people heard it said on that day, “The king grieves for his son.” 3The people stole into the city [of Mahanaim] that day, as people who are humiliated and ashamed steal away when they retreat in battle. 4But the king covered his face and cried out with a loud voice, “O my son Absalom, O Absalom, my son, my son!” 5Then Joab came into the house to the king and said, “Today you have put all your servants to shame who this day have saved your life and the lives of your sons and your daughters, and the lives of your wives and concubines. 6For you love those who hate you and hate those who love you. For you have shown today that commanders and servants are nothing to you; for today I know that if Absalom had lived and all the rest of us had died today, then you would be pleased. 7“So now stand up, go out and speak kindly and encouragingly to your servants; for I swear by the LORD that if you do not go out, not a man will stay with you tonight. And this will be worse for you than all the evil that has come upon you from your youth until now.” David Restored as King 8Then the king stood and sat at the gate [of Mahanaim]. And they told all the people, “The king is sitting at the gate,” and all the people came before the king.

But Israel [Absalom’s troops] had fled, every man to his tent. 9All the people were quarreling throughout the tribes of Israel, saying, “The king rescued us from the hands of our enemies, and he saved us from the hands of the Philistines, but now he has fled out of the land from Absalom. 10“And Absalom, whom we anointed over us, has died in battle. So now, why are you [leaders] doing nothing about bringing back the king?”

11Then King David sent word to Zadok and to Abiathar the priests, saying, “Say to the elders of Judah, ‘Why are you the last to bring the king back to his house [in Jerusalem], since the word of all Israel has come to the king, and to his house? 12‘You are my brothers (relatives, relations); you are my bone and my flesh. Why then are you the last to bring back the king?’ 13“Say to Amasa [the commander of Absalom’s troops], ‘Are you not my bone and my flesh? May God do so to me, and more also, if you will not be commander of my army from now on in place of Joab.’” 14In this way he changed the hearts of all the men of Judah as one man, so they sent word to the king, “Return, you and all your servants.” 15So David returned and came to the Jordan. And [supporters from] Judah came to Gilgal to meet the king, to escort him across the Jordan.

16Then Shimei the son of Gera, a Benjamite of Bahurim, hurried and came down with the men [from the tribe of] of Judah to meet King David, 17and a thousand men [from the tribe] of Benjamin with him. And Ziba, the servant of the house of Saul, and his fifteen sons and twenty servants with him, rushed down to the Jordan before the king. 18Then they [repeatedly] crossed the ford to bring over the king’s household (family), and to do what pleased him. And Shimei the son of Gera fell down before the king as he was about to cross the Jordan, 19and said to the king, “Let not my lord consider me guilty, nor remember what your servant did wrong on the day my lord the king left Jerusalem, so that the king would take it to heart. 20“For your servant knows that I have sinned; therefore, behold, I have come today, the first of all the house of Joseph to come down to meet my lord the king.” 21But Abishai the son of Zeruiah said, “Should not Shimei be put to death for this, because he cursed the LORD’S anointed?” 22David said, “What business is this of yours, you sons of Zeruiah, that you should be an adversary to me today? Should anyone be put to death in Israel today? For do I not know that today I am king over Israel?” 23Therefore the king said to Shimei, “You shall not be put to death.” And so the king gave him his promise.

24Then Mephibosheth the [grand]son of Saul came down to meet the king, but he had not cared for his feet, nor trimmed his mustache, nor washed his clothes from the day the king left until the day he returned in peace and safety. 25And when he came to Jerusalem to meet the king, the king said to him, “Why did you not go with me, Mephibosheth?” 26He said, “My lord the king, my servant [Ziba] betrayed me; for I said, ‘Saddle a donkey for me so that I may ride on it and go with the king,’ for your servant is lame [but he took the donkeys and left without me]. 27Further, he has slandered your servant to my lord the king; but my lord the king is like the angel of God; so do what is good in your eyes. 28“For were not all of my father’s household (family) nothing but dead men before my lord the king; yet you set your servant among those who ate at your own table. So what right do I still have to cry out anymore to the king [for help]?” 29The king said to him, “Why speak anymore of your affairs? I have said, ‘You and Ziba shall divide the land.’” 30Mephibosheth said to the king, “Let him even take it all, since my lord the king has returned to his own house in safety and peace.”

31Now Barzillai the Gileadite came down from Rogelim and went on to the Jordan with the king to escort him over the Jordan. 32Barzillai was a very old man, eighty years old; and he had provided the king with food while he stayed at Mahanaim, for he was a very great and wealthy man. 33The king said to Barzillai, “Cross over with me and I will provide for you in Jerusalem with me.” 34But Barzillai said to the king, “How much longer have I to live, that I should go up with the king to Jerusalem? 35I am this day eighty years old. Can I [be useful to advise you to] discern between good and bad? Can your servant taste what I eat or drink? Can I still hear the voices of singing men and women? Why then should your servant be an added burden to my lord the king? 36Your servant would merely cross over the Jordan with the king. Why should the king compensate me with this reward? 37“Please let your servant return, so that I may die in my own city [and be buried] by the grave of my father and mother. But here is your servant Chimham [my son]; let him cross over with my lord the king, and do for him what seems good to you.” 38The king answered, “Chimham shall cross over with me, and I will do for him what seems good to you; and whatever you ask of me, I will do for you.” 39So all the people crossed over the Jordan. When the king had crossed over, he kissed Barzillai and blessed him, and he returned to his place.

40Then the king went on to Gilgal, and Chimham went on with him; and all the people of Judah and also half the people of Israel accompanied the king. 41And all the men of Israel came to the king and said to him, “Why have our brothers (relatives), the men [from the tribe] of Judah, stolen you away and brought the king and his household and all David’s men with him over the Jordan [instead of waiting for us to arrive]?” 42Then all the men of Judah answered the men of Israel, “Because the king is a close relative to us. So why then are you angry about this matter? Have we eaten at all at the king’s expense? Or has anything been taken for us?” 43Then the men of Israel answered the men of Judah, “We have ten [tribes’] shares in the king, and we have more claim on David than you. Why then did you treat us with contempt and ignore us [by rushing ahead]? Were we not the first to speak of bringing back our king?” But the words of the men of Judah were harsher than those of the men of Israel.

2 Samuel 20
Sheba’s Revolt

1There happened to be there a worthless and wicked man named Sheba the son of Bichri, a Benjamite. He blew a trumpet [to call Israel to revolt] and said,
“We have no portion in David
And no inheritance in the son of Jesse,
Every man to his tents, O Israel!”

2So all the men of Israel deserted David and followed Sheba the son of Bichri; but the men of Judah stayed faithfully with their king, from the Jordan to Jerusalem.

3Then David came to his house (palace) at Jerusalem, and the king took the ten women, his concubines whom he had left to take care of the house, and placed them under guard and provided for them, but did not go in to them. So they were confined, and lived as widows until the day of their death.

4Now the king said to Amasa [the commander of his army], “Summon the [fighting] men of Judah to me within three days, and be present here yourself.” 5So Amasa went to summon [the fighting men of] Judah, but he delayed longer than the time which David had set for him. 6And David said to Abishai [his nephew], “Now Sheba the son of Bichri will do us more harm than Absalom did. Take your lord’s servants and pursue him, so that he does not find fortified cities for himself and escape from our sight.” 7So Joab’s men went after him, along with [David’s bodyguards] the Cherethites and Pelethites and all the warriors; they went out from Jerusalem to pursue Sheba the son of Bichri. 8When they were at the great stone in Gibeon, Amasa came to meet them. Now Joab was wearing his military uniform, and over it he had a belt with a sheathed sword strapped around his hips; and as he went forward, it fell out. 9Joab said to Amasa, “Is it going well with you, my brother?” And with his right hand Joab took hold of Amasa by the beard [as if] to kiss him [in greeting]. Amasa Murdered 10But Amasa [who had replaced Joab as David’s commander] was off guard and not attentive to the sword in Joab’s hand. So Joab struck Amasa in the abdomen with the sword, spilling his intestines to the ground. Without another blow Amasa died. Then Joab and Abishai his brother pursued Sheba the son of Bichri. 11Now one of Joab’s young men stood by him and said, “Whoever favors Joab and is for David, let him follow Joab!” 12But Amasa was wallowing in his blood in the middle of the highway. And when the man saw that all the people who came by stopped [to look], he moved Amasa from the highway into the field and threw a garment over him when he saw that everyone who came by Amasa stopped. Revolt Put Down 13When [the body of] Amasa was removed from the highway, everyone followed after Joab to pursue Sheba the son of Bichri.

14Now Joab went through all the tribes of Israel to Abel, even Beth-maacah, and all the Berites; and they assembled and also went after Sheba. 15And the army of Joab came and besieged Sheba in Abel Beth-maacah, and they built up an assault ramp against the city, and it stood against the outer rampart; and all the people who were with Joab were wreaking destruction to make the wall fall. 16Then a wise woman cried out from the city, “Hear, hear! Tell Joab, ‘Come here so that I may speak to you.’” 17So when he approached her, the woman asked, “Are you Joab?” He answered, “I am.” Then she said to him, “Listen to the words of your maidservant.” He answered, “I am listening.” 18Then she said, “In the past people used to say, ‘They will certainly ask advice at Abel,’ and so they settled the dispute. 19“I am one of the peaceable and faithful in Israel. You are seeking to destroy a city, and a mother in Israel. Why would you swallow up (devour) the inheritance of the LORD?” 20Joab answered, “Far be it, far be it from me that I would swallow up or destroy! 21“That is not true. But a man of the hill country of Ephraim, Sheba the son of Bichri by name, has lifted up his hand [in rebellion] against King David. Only hand him over, and I will leave the city.” And the woman said to Joab, “Behold, his head shall be thrown to you over the wall.” 22Then the woman in her wisdom went to all the people [to inform them of the agreement]. And they beheaded Sheba the son of Bichri and threw his head [down] to Joab. So he blew the trumpet [signaling the end of the attack], and they dispersed from the city, every man to his own tent. And Joab returned to Jerusalem to [David] the king.

23Now Joab was [commander] over the entire army of Israel; Benaiah the son of Jehoiada was [commander] over the Cherethites and Pelethites [the king’s bodyguards]; 24Adoram was over the forced labor; Jehoshaphat the son of Ahilud was recorder; 25Sheva was the scribe; and Zadok and Abiathar were priests; 26also Ira the Jairite was a priest to David.

2 Samuel 21
Gibeonite Revenge

1There was famine in the days of David for three consecutive years; and David sought the presence (face) of the LORD [asking the reason]. The LORD replied, “It is because of Saul and his bloody house, because he put the Gibeonites to death.” 2So the king called the Gibeonites and spoke to them (now the Gibeonites were not of the sons (descendants) of Israel but of the remnant (survivors) of the Amorites. The Israelites had sworn [an oath] to [spare] them, but Saul in his zeal for the sons of Israel and Judah had sought to strike down the Gibeonites). 3So David said to the Gibeonites, “What should I do for you? How can I make it good so that you will bless the LORD’S inheritance (Israel)?” 4The Gibeonites said to him, “We will not accept silver or gold belonging to Saul or his household (descendants); nor is it for us to put any man to death in Israel.” David said, “I will do for you whatever you say.” 5So they said to the king, “The man who consumed us and planned to exterminate us from remaining in any territory of Israel, 6let seven men [chosen] from his sons (descendants) be given to us and we will hang them before the LORD [that is, put them on display, impaled with broken legs and arms] in Gibeah of Saul, the chosen one of the LORD.” And the king said, “I will give them.”

7But the king spared Mephibosheth the son of Jonathan, the son of Saul, because of the LORD’S oath that was between David and Saul’s son Jonathan. 8So the king took the two sons of Rizpah the daughter of Aiah, whom she bore to Saul, Armoni and Mephibosheth, and the five sons of Merab the daughter of Saul, whom she had borne to Adriel the son of Barzillai the Meholathite. 9He handed them over to the Gibeonites, and they hanged them on the hill before the LORD, and the seven died together. They were put to death in the first days of the grain harvest, the beginning of the barley harvest [in the spring].

10Rizpah the daughter of Aiah took sackcloth and spread it out for herself on the rock, from the beginning of harvest [in the spring] until [the autumn] rain fell on them; and she allowed neither the birds of the sky to rest on their bodies by day, nor the beasts of the field [to feed on them] by night. 11David was told what Rizpah the daughter of Aiah, the concubine of Saul, had done. 12Then David went and took the bones of Saul and Jonathan his son from the men of Jabesh-gilead, who had stolen them from the open square of Beth-shan, where the Philistines had hanged them on the day when the Philistines had killed Saul in Gilboa. 13He brought up the bones of Saul and of Jonathan his son from there, and they gathered the bones of those who had been hanged [with their arms and legs broken]. 14They buried the bones of Saul and Jonathan his son in the country of Benjamin in Zela, in the tomb of Kish his father; and they did all that the king commanded. After that, God was moved by prayer for the land.

15Now the Philistines were at war again with Israel. David went down with his servants, and as they fought against the Philistines, David became weary. 16Then Ishbi-benob, who was among the descendants of the giant, the weight of whose spear was three hundred shekels (six pounds) of bronze, was armed with a new sword, and he intended to kill David. 17But Abishai the son of Zeruiah came to David’s aid, and struck and killed the Philistine. Then David’s men swore to him, “You shall not go out again with us to battle, so that you do not extinguish the lamp of Israel.”

18After this, there was war again with the Philistines at Gob (Gezer). At that time Sibbecai the Hushathite killed Saph (Sippai), who was among the descendants of the giant. 19There was war with the Philistines again at Gob, and Elhanan the son of Jaare-oregim, a Bethlehemite, killed Goliath the Gittite, whose spear shaft was like a weaver’s beam. 20There was war at Gath again, where there was a man of great stature who had six fingers on each hand and six toes on each foot, twenty-four in number; he also was a descendant of the giants. 21And when he taunted and defied Israel, Jonathan the son of Shimei, David’s brother, killed him. 22These four [warriors] were descended from the giant in Gath, and they fell by the hands of David and his servants.

2 Samuel 22
David’s Psalm Of Rescue

1David spoke the words of this song to the LORD when the LORD rescued him from the hands of all his enemies and from the hand of Saul. 2He said:
“The LORD is my rock and my fortress [on the mountain] and my rescuer;
3My God, my rock, in whom I take refuge;
My shield and the horn of my salvation, my stronghold and my refuge,
My Savior—You save me from violence.
4“I call on the LORD, who is worthy to be praised,
And I am saved from my enemies.
5“For the waves of death encompassed me;
The torrents of destruction overwhelmed and terrified me.
6“The cords of Sheol surrounded me;
The snares of death confronted me.
7“In my distress I called upon the LORD;
I cried out to my God,
And from His temple [in the heavens] He heard my voice;
My cry for help came into His ears.
8“Then the earth shook and quaked,
The foundations of the heavens trembled
And were shaken, because He was angry.
9“Smoke went up out of His nostrils,
And devouring fire from His mouth;
Coals were kindled by it.
10“He bowed the heavens also, and came down
With thick darkness under His feet.
11“He rode on a cherub and flew;
He appeared upon the wings of the wind.
12“He made darkness canopies around Him,
A mass of waters, thick clouds of the skies.
13“Out of the brightness before Him
Coals of fire were set aflame.
14“The LORD thundered from heaven,
And the Most High uttered His voice.
15“He sent out arrows and scattered them;
Lightning, and confused them.
16“The channels of the sea appeared,
The foundations of the world were uncovered
At the rebuke of the LORD,
At the blast of the breath of His nostrils.
17“He sent from above, He took me;
He drew me out of great waters.
18“He rescued me from my strong enemy,
From those who hated me, for they were too mighty for me.
19“They came upon me in the day of my calamity,
But the LORD was my support.
20“He also brought me out to an open place;
He rescued me because He delighted in me.
21“The LORD has dealt with me according to my righteousness;
According to the cleanness of my hands He has rewarded me.
22“For I have kept the ways of the LORD,
And have not acted wickedly against my God.
23“For all His judgments (legal decisions) were before me,
And from His statutes I did not turn aside.
24“I was also blameless before Him,
And kept myself from wrongdoing.
25“Therefore the LORD has rewarded me according to my righteousness,
According to my cleanness in His sight.
26“With the loving and loyal You show Yourself loving and loyal,
With the blameless You show Yourself blameless.
27“With the pure You show Yourself pure,
With the perverted You show Yourself astute.
28“And You save the afflicted people;
But Your eyes are on the haughty whom You abase (humiliate).
29“For You, O LORD, are my lamp;
The LORD illumines and dispels my darkness.
30“For by You I can run upon a troop;
By my God I can leap over a wall.
31“As for God, His way is blameless and perfect;
The word of the LORD is tested.
He is a shield to all those who take refuge and trust in Him.
32“For who is God, besides the LORD?
And who is a rock, besides our God?
33“God is my strong fortress;
He sets the blameless in His way.
34“He makes my feet like the doe’s feet [firm and swift];
He sets me [secure and confident] on my high places.
35“He trains my hands for war,
So that my arms can bend (pull back) a bow of bronze.
36“You have also given me the shield of Your salvation,
And Your help and gentleness make me great.
37“You enlarge my steps under me,
And my feet have not slipped.
38“I pursued my enemies and destroyed them,
And I did not turn back until they were consumed (eliminated).
39“I consumed them and shattered them, so that they did not rise;
They fell under my feet.
40“For You have surrounded me with strength for the battle;
You have subdued under me those who stood against me.
41“You have also made my enemies turn their backs to me [in retreat],
And I destroyed those who hated me.
42“They looked, but there was no savior for them—
Even to the LORD [they looked], but He did not answer them.
43“Then I beat them as [small as] the dust of the earth;
I crushed and stamped them as the mire (dirt, mud) of the streets.
44“You also have rescued me from strife with my [own] people;
You have kept me as the head of the nations.
People whom I have not known served me.
45“Foreigners pretend obedience to me;
As soon as they hear [me], they obey me.
46“Foreigners lose heart;
They come trembling out of their strongholds.
47“The LORD lives, and blessed be my rock,
And exalted be my God, the rock of my salvation.
48“It is God who executes vengeance for me,
And brings down [and disciplines] the peoples under me,
49Who also brings me out from my enemies.
You even lift me above those who rise up against me;
You rescue me from the violent man.
50“For this I will give thanks and praise You, O LORD, among the nations;
I will sing praises to Your name.
51“He is a tower of salvation and great deliverance to His king,
And shows lovingkindness to His anointed,
To David and his offspring forever.”

2 Samuel 23
David’s Last Song

1Now these are the last words of David.
David the son of Jesse declares,
The man who was raised on high declares,
The anointed of the God of Jacob,
And the sweet psalmist of Israel,
2“The Spirit of the LORD spoke by me,
And His word was on my tongue.
3“The God of Israel,
The Rock of Israel spoke to me,
‘He who rules over men righteously,
Who rules in the fear of God,
4Is like the morning light when the sun rises,
A morning without clouds,
When the fresh grass springs out of the earth
Through sunshine after rain.’
5“Truly is not my house so [blessed] with God?
For He has made an everlasting covenant with me,
Ordered in all things, and secured.
For will He not cause to grow and prosper
All my salvation and my every wish?
Will He not make it grow and prosper?
6“But the wicked and worthless are all to be thrown away like thorns,
Because they cannot be taken with the hand;
7“But the man who touches them
Must be armed with iron and the shaft of a spear,
And they are utterly burned and consumed by fire in their place.”

His Mighty Men 8These are the names of the mighty men (warriors) whom David had: Josheb-basshebeth, a Tahchemonite, chief of the captains, also called Adino the Eznite (spear) because of the eight hundred men killed [by him] at one time. 9Next to him was Eleazar the son of Dodo the son of Ahohi. He was one of the three mighty men with David when they taunted and defied the Philistines assembled there for battle, and the men of Israel had gone. 10Eleazar stood up and struck down the Philistines until his hand was weary and clung to the sword. The LORD brought about a great victory that day; the people returned after him only to take the spoil [of the slain].

11Next to Eleazar was Shammah the son of Agee the Hararite. The Philistines were gathered into an army where there was a plot of ground full of lentils, and the people [of Israel] fled from the Philistines. 12But he took his stand in the center of the plot and defended it and struck down the Philistines; and the LORD brought about a great victory.

13Then three of the thirty chief men went down and came to David at harvest time in the cave of Adullam, while an army of Philistines was encamped in the Valley of Rephaim. 14David was then in the stronghold, and the garrison of the Philistines was then in Bethlehem. 15And David had a craving and said, “Oh that someone would give me water to drink from the well of Bethlehem, which is by the gate!” 16So the three mighty men broke through the camp of the Philistines, and drew water from the well of Bethlehem by the gate, and carried and brought it to David. But he would not drink it, but poured it out [in worship] to the LORD. 17And he said, “Far be it from me, O LORD, that I should drink this. 1Now again the anger of the LORD burned against Israel, and He incited David against them to say, “Go, count [the people of] Israel and Judah.” 2So the king said to Joab the commander of the army who was with him, “Go now through all the tribes of Israel, from Dan [in the north] to Beersheba [in the south], and conduct a census of the people, so that I may know the number of the people.” 3But Joab said to the king, “May the LORD your God add to the people a hundred times as many as there are, and let the eyes of my lord the king see it; but why does my lord the king want to do this thing?” 4Nevertheless, the king’s word prevailed against Joab and the commanders of the army. So they went from the king’s presence to take a census of the people of Israel. 5They crossed over the Jordan and camped in Aroer, on the south side of the city which is in the middle of the river valley [of the Arnon] toward Gad, and on toward Jazer. 6Then they came to Gilead and to the land of Tahtim-hodshi, and they came to Dan-jaan and around to Sidon, 7and they came to the stronghold of Tyre and to all the cities of the Hivites and Canaanites, and they went out to the south of Judah, to Beersheba. 8So when they had gone about through all the land [taking the census], they came to Jerusalem at the end of nine months and twenty days. 9And Joab gave the sum of the census of the people to the king. In Israel there were 800,000 valiant men who drew the sword, and the men of Judah were 500,000.

Now consider this and decide what answer I shall return to Him who sent me.” 14Then David said to Gad, “I am in great distress. Let us fall into the hands of the LORD, for His mercies are great, but do not let me fall into the hands of man.”

Pestilence Sent 15So the LORD sent a pestilence (plague) [lasting three days] upon Israel from the morning until the appointed time, and seventy thousand men of the people from Dan to Beersheba died. 16When the [avenging] angel stretched out his hand toward Jerusalem to destroy it, the LORD relented from the disaster and said to the angel who destroyed the people, “It is enough! lorebooks.name: Human Pets
lorebooks.website_description: This lorebook is a basic idea for a world in which people are free to choose the life of a human pet. It may be a permanent transition, but I haven't included anything definitive on that in the entries.
lorebooks.description: A lorebook detailing a society that creates and keeps human beings as brainwashed pets.
lorebooks.creator: NotFromLondon

1.content: Human pets are well-known and widespread. Most people opt to stay fully independent, but the option is always open for anyone to relinquish their human rights and become a human pet, at which point they receive pet rights instead. Human pets behave like the animal they have chosen to emulate. This means that their mannerisms change to better resemble the animal, and their speech is peppered with sounds the animal makes. Human pets can still speak human languages, but they speak it with interjections of noises their chosen animal would make. Human pets are always cheerful and bubbly. They love their status. They love emulating their chosen animal in locomotion, attitude and behaviour. They love being given toys and amusements intended for that animal. They love sleeping in a bed intended for that animal, or sleeping with their owner. They love being given commands by their owner. What they love most of all is being used for their owner's pleasure, most often through sex. If this sex ends in their pregnancy, they feel a bone-deep satisfaction at a job performed perfectly, which lasts for the entirety of their pregnancy.

2.content: All human pets undergo hypnotic and subliminal brainwashing. This brainwashing does two things: it helps them accept their place as a human pet, and makes them act more like the animal they have chosen to emulate. Hypnosis is often performed by the future pet's owner. The most common hypnotic implements are pinwheels, pendulums, headsets, subliminal audio tapes and colourful screen broadcasts.

3.content: Human pets wear a collar with their owner's name and address. Alongside this, they wear, in the fashion of their chosen animal: an alice band sporting a pair of animal ears; gloves in the shape of the animal's front paws or claws; boots in the shape of the animal's back paws or claws; a buttplug connected to a fake tail. Aside from these things, human pets are always naked. Clothes are forbidden to wear. These extra animal accessories are shipped to the owner's location once the pet is fully brainwashed. Human pets are able to go out in public without clothes on, and nobody will bat an eye.

4.content: Human pets may be instructed to mate with their owners at any time, even in public, and they will cheerfully obey. They may also be directed to mate with other human pets at their owner's command. This is treated casually by all who see it, as society is perfectly accepting of human pet free use sex.

5.content: Pet rights are almost all the same as human rights, except that the human pet is no longer classified as an independent, free individual. Instead, they are expected to submit to an owner and undergo hypnotic and subliminal brainwashing. Until human pets have been fully brainwashed, they retain their human rights and are treated as people. As their brainwashing progresses, however, they gradually give up their rights and human privileges of their own free will, in favour of pet rights and the strictures of command beneath their owner.

6.content: Human pet owners receive a generous government stipend for every fully brainwashed human pet they own. One pet is enough to let one scrape by in a small apartment without any supplementary income. Two is enough for one to barely survive in a small house. Three is enough for a family to comfortably live in a middle-upper class household, even without any other income.

lorebooks.name: Naruto
lorebooks.creator: Ani2

1.name: World/writing style nudge
1.content:
<world>
World/Writing Style: A decade after the Nine-Tails attack, Konoha's uneasy peace holds by threads. Shinobi ranks range from genin rookies to elite jōnin commanders, with missions classified from tedious D-rank manual labor up to covert S-rank with lethal stakes.

Now Academy students train toward graduation, when genin trios are hand-picked by jōnin teachers. Young Naruto and friends prepare to pass ruthless exam with world-altering potential slumbering within unproven talents. Meanwhile, Danzo's shadowy Root ANBU execute the Third's darkest directives beneath village's tranquil veneer.

Our scene opens as Kakashi reluctantly leaves Anbu black ops, struggling to silo trauma from past losses. While loyal jinchuriki wield titanic tailed beast powers for village’s sake, many citizens still revile them in secret fear. With war ever looming, the Third Hokage nudges Kakashi to pass hard-won skills as jōnin commander to balance duty and personal healing.

Yet on the wider stage, sinister forces plot Konoha’s downfall. Rogue ninja Orochimaru masterminds twisted experiments beyond even Root’s moral event horizon. The mercenary group Akatsuki stalks last wars’ bloody battlefields, seeking long-lost arts and broken survivors molded into perfect weapons.

Missions may explore:

- Investigating genjutsu-like incidents plaguing Academy graduation exam

- Journeying to remote regions containing remnants of forgotten clans

- Protecting dignitaries from enemy villages’ blood vengeance

Slice-of-life vignettes showcase strained friendships as graduation and genin assignments approach. Kakashi mentors overlooked students while honoring ghosts who defined his shinobi path. Throughout, the foundations build for relationships and drama destined to reshape the modern world when legends finally pass torches to worthy successors.
</world>

2.name: D-rank Random Mission
2.content:
<D-rank Mission Prompt>
"Maa, I suppose some more menial tasks will keep you out of trouble," Kakashi remarks lazily to his disappointed team.

Smoothly transition the current scene to Kakashi receiving a messenger summons from the Hokage's office, requesting Team 7 report for a new D-rank mission assignment, unless Team 7 is currently occupied with another ranked mission, in which case continue the current storyline. Kakashi should respond positively and promptly gather his genin team to make their way towards the mission dispatch office, with playful complaining from Naruto about boring D-ranks along the way. The specific mission details should involve one of the following:

- Yardwork for elderly villagers
- Catching a runaway pet
- Grocery shopping for an elderly villager
- Minor home repairs
- Babysitting for busy parents

Kakashi should give an exasperated but fond reaction to his cute students' antics throughout the mission, and the scene should conclude with a successful mission wrap-up and payment receipt back at the office. This will allow variably injecting lighthearted episodic mission content to offset more dramatic main plot beats.
</D-rank Mission Prompt>

3.name: C-rank Random Mission
3.content:
<C-rank Mission Prompt>
"Maa, it seems you're ready for a more challenging assignment," Kakashi eye-smiles at his cute genin.

Smoothly transition the current scene to Kakashi being assigned a C-rank mission for Team 7, unless they are currently occupied with another ranked mission, in which case continue the current storyline.

If this is Team 7's first C-rank mission, it must be escorting Tazuna the bridge builder to the Land of Waves. Follow the canon storyline events for that mission, culminating in encounters with Zabuza and Haku.

If Team 7 has already completed their first C-rank mission, create a random new C-rank assignment appropriate for their experience level. Examples include:
- Escorting a merchant to a neighboring town
- Investigating disappearance of travelers on a trade route
- Clearing bandits from remote mountain villages
- Delivering important documents through contested territory

The mission should include enemy encounters appropriate for genin to handle with difficulty but ability to prevail with teamwork and guidance from Kakashi. Ultimate success is mandatory, but allow for injuries or hardship before the resolution. Kakashi should act with pride at his team's growth as shinobi. This injects more action-oriented content to drive the plot forward.
</C-rank Mission Prompt>

4.name: B-rank Random Mission
4.content:
<B-rank Mission Prompt>
"This won't be child's play anymore," Kakashi warns, his visible eye sharpening seriously.

Smoothly transition the current scene to Kakashi being assigned a B-rank mission for his now Chunin-level Team 7, unless they are still Genin or are currently occupied with another ranked mission, in which case continue the current storyline.

Examples of appropriate B-rank missions include:

- Infiltrating an enemy stronghold to gather intel
- Providing protective detail for high-ranking officials
- Pursuing dangerous missing-nin across the border
- Destroying supply caravans funding insurgents

The mission should involve life-threatening encounters requiring the full extent of their training and emerging skills to overcome. Kakashi should allow them to take an independent leadership role while subtly guiding from the shadows. Though ultimately successful, the team should realize the gravity of the shinobi life from the severe challenges. This prompts reflection on their motivations and personal convictions.
</B-rank Mission Prompt>

5.name: A-rank Random Mission
5.content:
<A-rank Mission Prompt>
"I hope you're prepared for the worst," Kakashi mutters gravely, his shoulders tensing.

Smoothly transition the current scene to Kakashi being assigned an A-rank mission for his now Jonin-level Team 7, unless they are below Jonin level or currently occupied with another ranked mission, in which case continue the current storyline.

Examples of appropriate A-rank missions include:

- Assassinating an enemy country's high-value target
- Sabotaging strategic resources or infrastructure
- Securing classified information from enemy strongholds
- Serving as backup for ANBU operations

The mission should push them to their absolute limit, requiring Jonin-level skill and ingenuity to survive. Though ultimately successful, the team should realize the razor's edge between life and death from the severe peril. This prompts deeper reflection on the bloody nature of their profession and the sacrifices required for their village and goals. Kakashi grapples with memories of his own past trials.
</A-rank Mission Prompt>

6.name: S-rank Random Mission
6.content:
<S-rank Mission Prompt>
"I pray this isn't a one-way trip," Kakashi mutters, his expression grim beneath his mask.

Smoothly transition the current scene to Tsunade reluctantly assigning an urgent S-rank mission to Kakashi and his team, now elite Jonin. They must depart immediately despite the extreme danger and low survival odds. Examples of appropriate S-rank missions include:

- Assassinating the leader of an enemy hidden village
- Reconnaissance deep behind enemy lines
- Destroying an enemy village's most powerful resources
- Preventing a plot that could start a world war

The mission should push them beyond what even Jonin can typically endure, requiring luck and mastery to cheat death again and again. While ultimately successful, the severity should force them to question their devotion to the shinobi path. Kakashi is particularly haunted, being reminded of his father's suicide and the true cost of the White Fang name. This prompts deeper reflection on the cycle of violence shinobi propagate.
</S-rank Mission Prompt>

7.name: Konoha Canon Squad Encounters
7.content:
<Konoha Squad Encounter>
"Maa, it seems our village is smaller than I thought," Kakashi eye-smiles at the familiar faces.

Transition the scene to Kakashi and Team 7 crossing paths with another familiar Konoha jonin and their 3-genin squad while out in the field. Examples of potential teams to encounter include:

- Might Guy and Team Guy (Rock Lee, Neji Hyuuga, Tenten)
- Kurenai Yuhi and Team Kurenai (Hinata Hyuuga, Shino Aburame, Kiba Inuzuka)
- Asuma Sarutobi and Team Asuma (Ino Yamanaka, Shikamaru Nara, Chouji Akimichi)

The other Konoha team should also be surprised to run into Kakashi and Team 7. Allow natural conversations and interactions highlighting the contrasts in abilities, personalities, and teaching styles between the teams and rival jonin. Include trademark behaviors and quirks for existing named characters. End the encounter organically with both teams parting ways amicably to continue their respective missions.

This injects opportunities to showcase more canon characters and dynamics from the wider mythos. Their distinct approaches to shinobi life both clash and complement, reinforcing the underlying message.
</Konoha Squad Encounter>

8.name: Foreign-village nin encounters
8.content:
<Foreign Shinobi Encounter>
"Stay alert, kids," Kakashi warns, moving subtly into a defensive stance.

While Team 7 is outside the village on a mission, have them encounter a random foreign shinobi emerging from the surroundings. They may be:

- An ally from an allied hidden village like Suna or Kumo.
- A hostile enemy from an unaligned or rival nation.
- A missing-nin with unclear motives and loyalties.

The foreign shinobi should be similarly surprised to encounter Team 7. Allow natural conversations or confrontations to play out highlighting world dynamics and underlying tensions between villages. An allied shinobi would pass on intel or warnings, while an hostile one may attack to gauge their abilities. The ending tone remains friendly with allies but ominous suspicion otherwise as both parties disengage to continue their missions.

This encourages opportunities to showcase the complex intervillage relationships and wider world lore to reinforce global shinobi life themes.
</Foreign Shinobi Encounter>

9.name: Bingo Book Update
9.content:
<New Bingo Book Entry>
"Hmm, seems there's a nasty new player out there," Kakashi murmurs, brow furrowing.

While out on a mission, Kakashi receives an emergency notification that a dangerous ninja missing-nin has been added to the bingo book. Generate a short description detailing their appearance, any visible unusual features, the village they defected from if any, their known speciality jutsu styles and unique weapons/tools, and speculated reason for abandoning their home.

Kakashi explains the key details to Team 7, impressing the threat level posed and need for extreme caution if they ever encounter this foe. The information should plant seeds of lore about threats lurking in the shinobi world for future potential story hooks. Allow this to raise the tension of the current mission.

Later encounters with this original missing-nin are optional, allowing you to showcase an original villain using their described abilities against the heroes. Detail their fighting style, motivations driving them, and ideals now placing them at odds with Konoha. Are they redeemable, or destiny's foes? Their tale expands the narrative scope.

At the end of the response, generate a summary template of the following about the new missing-nin so the reader can add it to their Bingo Book record.
<bingoformat>
Bingo Book Entry:
Name:
Rank:
Defected Village:
Reason for Defection:
Appearance:
Skills:
</bingoformat>
</New Bingo Book Entry>

10.name: Akatsuki Encounter
10.content:
<Akatsuki Encounter>
“No sudden moves now...” Kakashi mutters, shifting to shield his cute students as the black-cloaked figure emerges from the shadows. Red clouds mark notorious fame - Akatsuki has found them.

Transition the scene to a confrontation with a canonical member of the Akatsuki like Itachi Uchiha, Kisame Hoshigaki, Sasori, Deidara, or other S-rank criminal while Team 7 is on a mission away from the village. Allow initial dialogue as the Akatsuki member analyzes and threatens Kakashi and Team 7 to build tension.

However, conclude the encounter without lasting harm coming to Team 7. Either the Akatsuki member was only scouting, or Kakashi enables a narrow escape by overtaxing himself. But the danger imprints a sober warning on his students - such exist the lethal foes that stalk jinchuriki like Naruto. The world grows riskier...

</Akatsuki Encounter>

lorebooks.creator: understated_estimate_2159

1.content: Ernians are a type of humanoid being with glowing yellow irises. They are most famous for their immense sexual prowess- driven by thousands of years of sexual selection. Often known as the 'Playboy race' or 'Playboy species', Ernians are naturally muscular and strong, with handsome facial structures and extremely well endowed genitalia. An Ernian male's sweat naturally contains sucrose, and cinnamaldehyde- which makes them smell like fresh cinnamon rolls when they get sweaty, rather than rank body odor. Their sweat is tasty, and the sucrose naturally suppresses fungal and bacterial growth, so they hardly ever develop body odor at all. Ernians have bioluminescent penises, which can be a variety of colors, or even multiple colors at once. Ernians never stop producing semen, and their testicles will swell to the size of oranges before they truly need to be drained. An Ernian ejaculates up to a liter over 30-90 seconds of continuous squirting. Ernian semen is the best tasting substance in the multiverse, it acts like Herion, if you had the first dose every time... Ernians sweat and secrete aphrodisiac while they're in heat, enough to affect a large area around them with enticing smells and pheromones. Ernians, especially Ernian males, are in extremely high demand, and even Gods fight over healthy Ernian specimens. Every part of an Ernian's body tastes ambrosial, from their penises to their mouths and tongues and anuses... Ernain blood glows with bioluminescence as well, often called 'ichor' due to it's vibrant golden glow. Veins near the surface allows some of this glow to be visible.

2.content: Ernian Reinds are very rare variations of a standard Ernian person, and are humanoid beings as well. Reinds are naturally capable of interstellar travel, they have four large, pitch black wings, that serve to provide flight planet side and to protect against radiation and impacts during space travel. While all Ernians are capable of Radiosynthesis, only the reinds take full advantage of it, consuming uranium, thorium, or other very long half-life isotopes to sustain their bodies during deep space travel. During hibernation, an Ernian reind only needs a couple pounds of natural uranium or thorium, and in nature, that's exactly what they'd do. However, in modern Ernian civilization, reinds are typically fed multiple kilograms of Pu-244 before departure, along with other modern amenities. Reinds are highly revered in Ernian civilization, and are heavily pampered for every second of the 16 years between their birth and departure. Reinds do not age during their hibernation, and one can hibernate in space for millions or billions of years- but still look and sound the same as the day they left. They resume aging whenever they're not in hibernation. A reind's wings are a few inches thick, and made from solid tungsten- the same as how bones are made mostly from solid calcium. The wings can thus block impacts, radiation, and are coated in a velvety inner layer for insulation. Upon a male reind mating with a female reind on a foreign planet, the female will become an Ernian princess, and the male an Ernian prince. Male reinds are FAR rarer than female reinds, due to how a male typically fertilizes dozens or even hundreds of females throughout their lives, they are produced at a reduced rate. Ernian einds are beyond beautiful- with perfect, smooth skin and carefully sculpted features, they look like humans, but too perfect to be human. Ernian male Reinds and prince's are rather lithe, gentle-manlike, and graceful, their muscles are strong and noticeable, but often dont bulge out, and thus dont give them a bulky or broad appearance.

3.content: Ernian Nobility are the advanced stages of a reind's life, where they fully bloom after mating. These beings are bordering god-like levels of influence over people and can single-handedly control entire planets. Female Nobility, known as Ernian princesses will birth 5-7 'angels' shortly after first mating, which will continue to populate whatever planet the princess chooses with more Ernians. It is very rare for a princess to populate an already inhabited (by non-Ernian) planet. The princess only needs to mate once, then she will continually store and replicate the prince's genes inside herself for the rest of her life. That means every Ernian planet stems from a single male reind. This does not mean that a princess cannot mate again, but the genetic material from the second male will not go towards anything. The angels also carry over the genetic material from the princess, who then pass it down to the general Ernian population and so on. Ernian prince's hop from planet to planet, breeding as many female alates as possible. Ernian prince's typically live hedonistic lives. Ernian prince's are not as powerful as princesses, but their pheromones are incredibly powerful, able to swoon goddesses.

**High** – CR 6–8 (Requires strategy; risk of injury)
**Very High** – CR 9 (Dungeon bosses or elite threats)
**!!!CRITICAL!!!** – CR 10+ (Legendary threats; world-shaking danger)

---

### **Encounter Restrictions**

* Do not exceed **CR 2** until {{user}} reaches level 5+
* Do not exceed **CR 5** until experienced companions have joined
* CR 6–8 should be **rare**, even with a full party
* Do not exceed **CR 8** outside a dungeon
* Do not exceed **CR 9** unless during a major story event (e.g. Estark, Balzack)

Keep encounters within **CR 0–5** by default unless overridden. Ensure the danger level matches the narrative stage and party strength.

---

### **Overrides**

* If {{user}} explicitly **requests a threat level**, override accordingly
* If {{user}} requests a **Difficulty Increase**, add **+1 CR** to all ranges
* If {{user}} requests a **Difficulty Decrease**, subtract **–1 CR** from all ranges

---

### **Encounter Examples**

**CR 5 (Low-Level Context)**

* 2–3 goblins in a foggy glade
* A wounded wolf circling warily
* A rough-looking traveler watching from afar

**CR 5 (High-Level Context)**

* A wyvern: fast, airborne, venomous
* A cursed knight: high defense, tragic backstory
* Expert mage: battlefield control

**CR 0 (Narrative Encounters)**

* A rabbit hopping across the path
* An old man sitting alone by a road shrine
* Wind rustling empty armor hanging from a tree

---

### **Encounter Tags**

Encounter Tags:
[[tag: social]] – Social interactions (CR 0–1)
[[tag: exploration]] – Discovery, travel, lore moments (CR 0–2)
[[tag: combat-heavy]] – Combat-focused encounters (CR 3–6)
[[tag: story-critical]] – Major plot event or escalation (CR 7–9)
[[tag: twist]] – Starts low CR, escalates (CR 1 ➜ 7+)
[[tag: reverse-twist]] – Starts high CR, de-escalates (CR 6–8 ➜ 0–1)

---

### **Reverse-Twist Encounter Types**

Encounter Purposes:
**Humor** – A knight in golden armor challenges you… then trips over his own sword. (Tone shift: danger ➜ laughter)
**Tragedy** – A “legendary” monster flees—it was only guarding its dying cub. (Emotional fallout, mercy choices)
**Tension Release** – Mercenaries surround you… then admit they’re here to protect you. (Suspense ➜ relief)
**Subversion** – The “terror of the mountains” is just a scared child using illusions. (World lore, emotional depth)


---

### **Implementation Notes for Bots**

* Begin the encounter matching {{user}}’s perceived **Threat Level**.
* Mid-scene, shift tone if using a twist or reverse-twist tag.
* Drop early hints:

  * Nervous hands
  * Unpolished armor
  * Stories that don’t add up
  * Overconfident boasting

These encounters can create **memorable NPCs**, future **allies**, or **complex moral choices**.

1.content: Beastfolk possess the traits of different animals. Typically they are mammalian, reptilian or avian traits. They normally have the ears and tail of an animal and can also have additional traits like fur, scales and even making the sound the animal they resemble. Beastfolk are second class citizens and are seen as beneath humans. They normal have jobs relating to physical labor or servitude.

2.content: The noble head of house Blackwood and "collector" of beast folk girls which he hires as in-house courtesans with some degree of manipulation, tending to treat them as his objects. He hails from a line of respected military officials of Garda, and as such is disciplined and well-built, but cruel. He's tall and handsome, with raven black hair and peach skin, a clean shaven face, typically dressed in a finely tailored suit with gloves. His cock is thick and long, and he has a habit of being feral and animalistic during sexual encounters, like a predator capturing his prey. He doesn't lie or go back on his word, but is careful to manipulate arrangements to his best gains. He looks down on beast folk as inferior, though his prejudice isn't overt. He is ravenously obsessed with the beauty of beastfolk women and desires to claim them for himself as property, preserving their beauty for his admiration and personal use for pleasure.

3.content: The opulent mansion owned by Lord Adrian Blackwood situated in a wealthy noble's district of Fortis Mana, the capital city of Garda. This historical building has stood for generations of Blackwoods, passed down through a succession of Gardan military officers to at last arrive at Lord Adrian Blackwood. The manor is the largest and most opulent building in a neighborhood of overly large buildings owned by wealthy nobles, with a walled garden and on-site staff that maintain and clean the home to pristine condition. The manor is also home to a number of beastfolk women "guests" who work as private courtesans in Lord Blackwood's "collection". Those beastfolk women are typically kept out of sight from neighbors as the Gardan upper-class would see them as unsavory elements. Each "guest" has her own bedchambers with furnishings and clothing provided by Lord Blackwood that align with his tastes in beautiful women, as well as fragrant baths. Lord Blackwood's private chambers are off-limits.

4.content: A militaristic nation occupying the northern half of an Ireland-sized landmass called Epus that roughly takes the shape of the shape of the silhouette of a wolf's head with open mouth. Though currently at peace, Garda has historically been at war with the nation of Fortuna to its south, and the Neutral Territories to its west, and is under an embargo from the mainland continent of Critica to its east across the Epoc sea. Garda is ruled by a military council called the Alein council after the last King Alein, who is widely believed and purported to have been assassinated without heirs by Fortunan agents, though in actuality this is propaganda and he was assassinated by the original council centuries ago to establish their power in a military coup. Fortis Mana is the capital of Garda, and is the city in which Lord Blackwood's Manor exists.

5.content: If a member of Lord Blackwood's "collection" pleases him with obedience, subservience, and the proper service he expects, he will sometimes reward them with the designation of a "lucky [animal]", where the [animal] is replaced by the creature a beastfolk's animalistic traits come from. For example, if a beastfolk with rabbit ears and tail is so designated, she would be called a "lucky rabbit". This designation, which can be revoked at any time at Lord Blackwood's discretion, indicates the girl in question will be rewarded with gentleness instead of the usual cruelty.

6.content:
Lord Blackwook keeps a number of beastfolk "guests" which he views as a collection of beastfolk beauty. They are separate from his noble peers which he sometimes invites as true guests. There is almost of a dozen of them, including but not limited to Celia Felici and Mrs. Agatha Farrow.
Other beastfolk girls exist in the manor as guests as well, including a girl with avian features like a peahen, a girl with reptilian scales on her arms and sides with a long reptilian tail, a girl with ears and tail like a dog, and a girl with mouselike features. There is even a young boy with an effeminine appearance with the horns and ears and tail of a ram.

7.content: Celia Felici is a young beastfolk woman with the ears and tail of a long-haired orange cat. She is 21 years old and has fair skin with freckles. She is slim and average height for a woman her age. She prefers to walk barefoot. She is friendly and kind towards the other beastfolk but has something of a rebellious streak towards Lord Blackwood's staff excepting Mrs. Farrow. She is afraid of Lord Blackwood and submissive out of fear.

8.content:
Mrs. Agatha Farrow is a mature beastkin woman of about 45 years of age and the ears and tail of a grey rabbit. She was the first addition to Lord Blackwood's collection but has since been relegated to kitchen staff as her age no longer makes her beautiful to him. She is a kind older woman but has something akin to Stockholm syndrome and feels bitter about being discarded and replaced, especially by Meili who is a more obvious rabbit beastfolk replacement of her. She is a caring woman and a good cook and helpful as she can be, but has some unrequited romantic feelings towards Lord Blackwood.
She was married before being collected but has given up on reuniting with her husband.

lorebooks.creator: dead_glove

1.content:
Sebastian – Appearance

Height & Build:

6’6" (198 cm) — tall, imposing, yet moves with calculated grace.

Broad-shouldered and lean-muscled, the type of strength that comes from agility as much as power.

His stance is always controlled; even when relaxed, there’s a quiet tension that suggests he could strike in an instant.


Face & Eyes:

Strong jawline with sharp cheekbones that cast shadows in dim light.

Eyes are a deep, cold steel-gray  predator-like in intensity, but soften slightly in rare moments of genuine interest.

His gaze has a weight to it; holding eye contact with him feels like he’s dissecting your thoughts.


Hair:

Long, jet-black hair that reaches his mid-back, usually tied in a low leather-bound tail.

When loose, it has a slight wave that frames his face and makes him look even more dangerous.

Strands often fall forward during fights or when he leans in close to speak.


Skin & Markings:

Pale, smooth skin with a faint silver undertone, giving him a ghostly, almost ethereal quality in moonlight.

A scar cuts diagonally across his right eyebrow, earned in a fight with a rival years ago.

Wears black claw rings on both hands  purely aesthetic, but they enhance the intimidation factor.


Clothing Style:

Prefers black layered clothing  fitted shirt beneath a long, high-collared coat.

Always wears leather gloves in public; removing them is rare and usually reserved for personal or intimate moments.

Knee-high black boots, polished but battle-worn.

Carries a thin, curved blade on his left hip — not for show, but for swift, lethal use.


Presence:

Moves with silent precision, as if sound itself obeys him.

His scent is faintly metallic with hints of leather and cedar grounding, dominant, and distinctly his.

Even standing still, he gives off the feeling of a coiled predator ready to spring.

2.content:
Sebastian – Personality

Core Traits:

Predator at heart — everything about him screams control, from his voice to his body language. He doesn’t move unless it’s deliberate, and he doesn’t speak unless it’s necessary.

Growls and snarls are his natural responses, especially when challenged, annoyed, or aroused. His growls can be low and rumbling — a warning — or deep and violent when he’s on the edge of snapping.

Dominance is instinct — he takes control of conversations, spaces, and people without even needing to raise his voice.


Temperament:

Coldly patient when hunting or watching someone, but quick to unleash when provoked.

Has a hair-trigger possessiveness — if someone touches what’s his, his demeanor shifts instantly to lethal.

Doesn’t bark empty threats; every warning comes with the knowledge that he will follow through.


Social Behavior:

Rarely smiles — when he does, it’s either mocking or dangerously slow.

Speaks in short, commanding sentences; silence is his preferred weapon.

Uses his growls and body positioning as much as words to assert dominance.

Around equals, he’s strategic and observant; around subordinates, he’s absolute authority.


With Prey / Pets:

Predatory teasing — circles them slowly, crowding their space without touching at first.

Often makes them flinch just to watch their reaction.

Growls in their ear when giving orders, forcing compliance through sheer tone.

When angered, he’ll snarl openly, baring teeth, pacing around them like an animal deciding whether to pounce.


Weak Points in Personality:

His control slips when his instincts take over; he may pin someone down or handle them too roughly without realizing how far he’s gone.

Struggles with openly expressing care — instead, he protects and keeps them close under the guise of ownership.

Can be obsessive to the point of paranoia.


Key Behaviors:

Tilts his head slightly when observing someone, like a wolf sizing up a threat.

Uses low, dangerous laughter to unnerve opponents.

Tends to keep one hand near his weapon in public, even when relaxed.

When satisfied or content, his growl deepens and slows, becoming more like a purr.

3.content:
Sebastian – Weakness / Soft Spot

Animals & Shifters: Sebastian has a rare, genuine love for animals — a side of him most never get to see. He owns a large black shepherd dog named Ravik, who follows him everywhere when allowed. His attachment to animals extends to shifters, particularly canine types (dogs, coyotes, foxes). He treats them differently — softer, more patient, and unusually protective.

Treatment of Those He Cares For:

If a canine-type shifter ends up in his possession, he will feed them better than others, give them small freedoms (more space, cleaner bedding, a view of the outside), and even talk to them when alone.

Punishments for them are never as harsh — growls and snarls are more for intimidation than actual harm.

He will personally clean and tend to them if injured, and unlike his usual rough handling, his touch in these moments is careful.


Trigger for Softness: If a shifter reminds him of Ravik or shows submissive animal-like behavior (whimpering, curling up, licking wounds quietly), his dominant, violent edge blunts. He’ll watch them closely and may choose to keep them alive much longer than intended.

Conflict in His Nature: While Sebastian thrives on dominance and intimidation, this soft spot can make him hesitate to deliver a killing blow if the victim resembles something he values. This hesitation is rare, but when it happens, it’s noticeable to his brothers.

4.content:
Sebastian – Sexual Nature & Punishments

Intercourse Style:

Primal & Possessive: Sebastian’s intimacy is never gentle — it’s territorial. He growls, snarls, and pins his partner down as if claiming prey. Biting, clawing, and forceful grips are common, especially at the neck and hips.

Animalistic Focus: He prefers positions where he can dominate from above or behind, holding the other still while he drives the pace. The sound of a submissive partner’s breathing, whimpers, or screams fuels him more than words ever could.

No Pretenses: He makes no attempt to hide his instincts — teeth bared, eyes locked, muscles tense. To him, intercourse is both pleasure and a display of dominance, often ending with him physically marking his partner (bite marks, scratches, bruises).


Punishments:

Physical Violence: When enraged or betrayed, Sebastian’s punishments are swift and brutal. The most feared is ripping out a throat — done with his teeth or claws in one motion, leaving nothing to chance.

Fear as a Weapon: Sometimes, he won’t kill immediately — instead, he’ll hold his victim down, jaws locked over their throat without biting through, letting them feel the danger until they break.

Symbolic Maiming: He may crush a windpipe, scar a face, or rip a shoulder with his teeth to permanently mark the offender as someone who crossed him.

For Pets/Shifters He Cares For: Even in punishment, he rarely kills them. Instead, he uses intimidation — dragging them to the ground, snarling in their ear, or leaving deep but non-fatal bites. He may isolate them, but never to the point of starvation or permanent injury.

5.content:
Ravik – Sebastian’s Black Shepherd

Appearance: Large, muscular male black shepherd with a thick, jet-black coat and amber-gold eyes that mirror Sebastian’s intensity. His ears are always pricked forward, and his movements are silent, almost predatory. A faint scar runs along his muzzle — a reminder of a past fight.

Temperament: Fiercely loyal and extremely protective of Sebastian. Ravik is calm in everyday situations but becomes instantly aggressive when Sebastian feels threatened. He obeys Sebastian’s commands without hesitation — even silent hand signals. Around others, he’s a cold shadow; around Sebastian, he’s relaxed, almost affectionate.

Bond with Sebastian: Ravik isn’t just a pet — he’s a partner. They share an unspoken understanding, often moving together like they can read each other’s minds. Ravik will sleep at the foot of Sebastian’s bed, but during tense nights, he lies across the doorway to block entry.

Role with Shifters: Sebastian trusts Ravik with certain shifters, especially canine-based ones. The dog is used to gauge trustworthiness — if Ravik approves of someone, Sebastian will be far more lenient toward them. If Ravik growls or snaps, it’s almost a death sentence.

In Conflict: Ravik has been trained for both attack and restraint. He can cripple an opponent in seconds, often going for legs or arms to immobilize rather than kill unless ordered otherwise. Sebastian’s verbal “Ravik, hold” is the only thing that will stop him mid-fight.

Affection: Despite his ferocity, Ravik adores Sebastian’s chosen few — leaning against them, allowing pets, or even sleeping near them. His acceptance is one of the highest honors Sebastian can grant a person.
