Level 0.01's properties are anything but beneficial. Wanderers who enter Level 0.01 are separated from all other lifeforms, and they are incapable of dying from starvation and terminal dehydration. Matter brought into the level will have their colors slowly fade to match the level's dull yellows. However, if Almond Water is applied to the affected areas, it can reverse the effects.
Entrances:
A concrete door labeled with "EXIT" in green neon letters leads to Level 0.01.
Extremely long hallways in Level 0 where the lights around start to flicker lead to Level 0.01.
When you try a noclip at Level 0, there is a very small chance of entering Level 0.01.
Exits:
Holes in the floor lead to The Void.
Some lights have crawlspaces above them. Entering this area leads to Level 28. Once a person climbs into the crawlspace, they cannot return to Level 0.01.
Due to the level's stability deteriorating as one goes further in, it is theoretically possible to noclip out after a certain distance.

4.content:
Level 0.23 of the Backrooms is a sublevel of Level 0, more commonly known as "Half Finished". The level is made up of offices that look as though they are in a factory, with the appearance of the Alone phenomenon making it so that it is impossible to find any other explorers on the level. The level has a similar design to Level 0; however, it has scattered windows and appears to be under construction. Some of the windows look out to just a wall, others look out into a bright blue sky that seems to be computer-generated.
Since the level is under construction, there are hazards present, including the collapse of ceilings/floors, ventilation, or lights going out. The perceived height is different for everyone, with some people reporting five floors, others reporting two, and even one. This also affects the perceived dangers; if someone only sees one floor, there would be no possibility of a collapse from the ceiling or floor.
This level appears not to have been disturbed for an extremely long time. It contains open cans, mouldy bread, dust, and various other abandoned objects. It is almost identical to Level 0.22, which leads some explorers to believe that the two levels may have been connected at one point in time but have split for unknown reasons.
Entities:
Clouds are something that can be seen outside the widows, floating in the sky. These clouds are exceptionally hostile and invasive. Disturbingly, if you make eye contact for a couple of seconds, they start to distort your very perception in strange, otherworldly ways. For a time, you might find yourself reliving the very best moments of your life— memories flooding your input processor—shadows from the past whispering in your ear; a familiar smell flows around you and reminds you of people, places, long gone, that you felt joy with. Soft, lyrical music might play and stir within you vaguely, a long-ago happening; the longing for something or someone that could be felt or heard from so long ago suddenly returned.
What you don't realize is that this beautiful, remembered moment is a trap for you. While you are entranced by the clouds, all the while your body rots from the inside out. Your lifeforce leaks away slowly, imperceptibly, and with it the world around you warps, distorts, and ultimately fades. The longer you stare at the clouds, the more the grasp on your reality becomes frayed. Eventually, after what feels like an eternity, the last thing you will remember will be the eyes of the clouds, cold, leaking into your perception as they blinked away, and then nothing; no sound, no sensation.
It is theorized that the bodies that are left behind are no longer composed of flesh but instead turn to dust or disappear completely, as though they never existed.
Entrances and Exits
Entrances:
Rarely, finding a door on Level 0 labeled "Next Project" will lead you here.
Entering a building that is under construction on Level 11 or Level 111 will bring one to this level.
Various unknown factors in Level 0.22 may lead here.
Exits:
Going through an exit door will lead you to Level 27 or back to Level 0.
Various unknown factors may lead back to Level 0.22.

5.content:
Level 0.5, also known as the “Chaotic Structure”, is a sublevel of Level 0.
Level 0.5 consists of an endless series of randomly segmented cubic/rectangular solids, all completely covered in carpets in varying shades of blue. The composition of these solids is unknown, as the carpet seems to be unbreakable, but they are believed to be made out of some kind of metal.
Notably, most carpets have straight black lines of varying thicknesses. All lines are parallel to the edge of the solid they are on and often have gaps. It is believed these gaps contain hidden messages but attempts to translate them have failed (with one exception).
While on the level, gravity only applies when on the face of a solid and pulls one "down" onto the face. Interestingly, one will always be pulled "down", regardless of which face they are on, allowing one to walk on all sides of a solid (including the “bottom”). Jumping between solids is possible, as there is no gravity while in midair.
More ceaseless carpeted cubes. 
All solids within the level are suspended in a light blue fog, which seemingly stretches on infinitely. This fog restricts vision to 10-100 feet depending on its thickness. Notably, the fog seems to dissipate depending on how far up a person travels, although it never disappears entirely. The fog also seems to be the light source for this level, with a soft white light emanating from it constantly.
The fog seems to be a mixture of water and Almond Water, but, though it retains the taste of Almond Water, the concentration of Almond Water within the fog is incredibly small, making it necessary to inhale large amounts for the Almond Water to begin having an effect. It is only possible to inhale the fog while not on solid ground.
Time is strange here—one may feel hungry one moment and the next feel full despite never eating. In addition, one's sense of time drastically varies, ranging from thinking one has been in the level for just seconds to hours. There is no way to keep time while here—there is no day/night cycle, or even anything resembling it, nor do people feel tired while at this level. One's senses of distance and direction are also altered here, making it impossible to travel in a straight line.
Many objects can be found within the level, mostly related to tabletop games, such as chess pieces, puzzle pieces, and dice. Attempting to pick up any object in the level (including ones brought in) will still work, although the size of objects changes based on perspective.
The Floating Lobby
If one travels far enough in this level, the level will begin to resemble Level 0. The carpet will slowly transition from shades of blue to a uniform gray and will become increasingly moist, while the lines within the carpet will disappear. The color of the fog will shift to a yellow, resembling the infamous wallpaper of Level 0. Interestingly, Qwerty (a level-exclusive entity) can still appear here, despite Level 0 having no entities.
It is believed that, if one travels far enough in this area, the transition to Level 0 will become complete, and one will be transported to Level 0. However, this is unconfirmed. 
Entities
One level-exclusive entity, known as "Qwerty", has been discovered.
Entrances:
Level 0.5 can only be accessed through "cutoffs" within Level 0. These "cutoffs" appear to be regular hallways/rooms of Level 0 cut in half by a large wall mirror, which completely blocks off the rest of the hallway or room. If one attempts to interact with, walk through, or no-clip through the mirror, they will fall through the floor. While falling, they will see a kaleidoscope of Level 0 transitioning into Level 0.5. Interestingly, entering Level 0.5 can take anywhere from seconds to days.
As of right now, it is believed these "cutoffs" occur when a "glitch" occurs within Level 0, or a portion of it somehow noclips onto itself.
Exits:
No stable exits to this level have been found. However, there are unconfirmed and unstable ones:
It is theorized that, if one travels far enough in the Floating Lobby, they will be transported back to Level 0.
Several wanderers have reportedly been able to escape through a variety of means, such as finding an oddly colored pillar, falling asleep or floating in the fog for a long period of time. However, none of these exits are stable.

6.content:
Level 0.67, often referred to as "The Cold Lobby," is a sub-level between Level 0 and Level 1.
Although Level 0.67 shares a very similar appearance to Level 0, there are key differences between the two. Firstly, Level 0.67 has inconsistent geometry, with walls shifting and reorienting themselves haphazardly. It is currently unknown what causes the walls to move, but because of this, traversing the level is very difficult, and due to the nature of the laser measuring instruments normally used, it is impossible to map out or measure this level. Additionally, the level is incredibly cold, with temperatures averaging approximately -89°C (-128.2°F) throughout the entire level. This makes the level almost uninhabitable, (unless you are sufficiently equipped to handle the harsh temperatures of Level 0.67,) and causes a myriad of conditions, which include but are not limited to: chilblains, frostbite, and hypothermia. Finally, the level has a generally blue tint that engulfs the entire level, save for the Twilight Zone, which will be further elaborated on.
The Stationary Period:
This is a period of time, usually lasting only 3 to 5 seconds, where all of the walls stop moving. These time periods are completely random, with no discernible logic to the timing between the pauses in movement. If a wall is in mid-motion and is clipping into another wall, ceiling, or floor, the wall will simply return to an unclipped position as though it never moved, only to snap back to that position or rotation as soon as the period is over.
The Active Period:
As implied, this is the period of time in which all walls are jutting around the level and moving haphazardly with no sense whatsoever. To this day, it is unknown what causes the walls to move. Measurements have revealed that a wall can spin up to 265° along the X, Y or Z axis, also being able to move along up to two of these axes at any given time, (there were [REDACTED] fatalities during measurements). The walls have also been measured to move up to 9 inches in any direction, ignoring the ceiling and floor of the level, and any other walls.
The Twilight Zone:
The Twilight Zone is an interesting region of Level 0.67. This area is a zone that can be found anywhere within the level and is very large in volume, (though, due to the geometrical instabilities, the exact size of this zone is unknown). The area is pitch black and absorbs any light sources that a wanderer tries to use. This dark effect is only visible from within the region, making it impossible to avoid accidentally walking into it. It is recommended to turn and walk in the opposite direction the moment you accidentally enter, to avoid any encounters with the Lurker.
Level 0.67 is home to a single entity, that being the Lurker. This entity is native to Level 0.67 and there have been no confirmed sightings of it within any other level.
Colonies and Outposts:
This level is devoid of colonies and outposts. There are many reasons for this, which are as follows:
The method of entrance is very complicated, making it impractical to establish a human colony within this level.
Level 0.67 contains absolutely no resources that a wanderer can utilize. Additionally, nothing can be grown in this level due to the level's harsh temperatures. Moreover, the temperature of the level makes it almost impossible to live in for a prolonged period of time. There can never be more than one person inside Level 0.67 at any given time. In the case that a wanderer attempts to enter the level whilst someone is already in it, they will simply be sent to another instance of the level. This makes human interaction impossible on the level.
Entrances:
To enter Level 0.67, you must follow very specific instructions, which are as follows:
Find a vent within Level 0. Enter, and begin crawling through it.
After an unknown amount of time, the vent will experience a temperature drop. This drop will be noticeable no matter what protective gear you wear.
Once the temperature drop occurs, begin crawling in the opposite direction for 0.5 miles. It makes no difference how far you travelled upon entry, it will always be 0.5 miles on the reverse journey
After you have crawled 0.5 miles in reverse, you will no-clip through the floor of the vent and end up in a room with two doors labelled COLD and HOT
You must go through the door labelled COLD. Once you do, you will be sent to a random location within Level 0.67.
Failure to complete any of these steps correctly will send you to an unknown location. No wanderer that failed to complete these steps was ever heard from again, therefore it is advised to be as careful as possible if you plan to go to this level.
As there have been no other documented or confirmed methods of entry into the level, you should not try to attempt any alternative entry methods.
Exits:
To exit Level 0.67, you can attempt to no-clip through a wall during the stationary period of the level. Successfully no-clipping in this scenario will send you to a random level between Level 2 and Level 41. There have been unconfirmed reports of people exiting Level 0.67 and ending up in the Hub, but the validity of these claims is unknown.

7.content:
Level 0.7, colloquially referred to as the “Dark Lobby” or "The Squeeze" is a sub-level of Level 0. While it shares many similarities with Level 0, such as its non-euclidean geometry and general appearance, it differs from it in many aspects. A notable difference is the lack of isolating effects present in Level 0, making travel in groups possible, although not recommended. The most noticeable difference is that Level 0.7 has no lights. You should have a flashlight, but it will likely go out after 6 minutes due to the properties of the Level. The walls and carpet are completely covered grime and mold, as opposed to Level 0's, which are in mostly pristine condition. Due to this, the smell of the level is an "unbearable stench," adding to Level 0.7's uninhabitable conditions. Another notable difference from Level 0's walls is their average height. They appear to be approximately half the height of the walls found in Level 0.
Level 0.7 mainly consists of noticeably narrow hallways -- approximately quarter the width of the ones found in Level 0. Being the most common structure, wanderers may frequently encounter interconnected hallways spanning kilometers.
The less common type of structure in Level 0.7 is a room, similar to the ones found in Level 0. They serve as intersections of sorts, connecting three hallways. Doors commonly found in rooms lead to further hallways. Derelict furniture can frequently be found in larger rooms, appearing to be a natural part of the level, although not serving any obvious purpose.
There is a seemingly random chance for useful objects in low amounts such as Almond Water, cellphones, flashlights, or various industrial objects to be found in rooms, although harmful objects, mainly Cashew Water, may also be found.

The Flickering:
The Flickering (Not to be confused to The Flicker) is an common event that occurs erratically in Level 0.7. The event usually affects an area of roughly one football pitch (69,330 square feet or 6,438 square meters), according to wanderers' accounts.
When the event begins, lightbulbs will appear hanging from the ceiling, illuminating the area. It is recommended to leave the area immediately after this happens or seek cover, under the derelict furniture for example, if leaving isn't possible. After approximately three minutes, all functioning light sources in the area, including artificial ones such as flashlights, will start to consistently flicker at an increasing speed, starting from 10 seconds down to an unrecordably small interval.
The constant turn-on and turn-off cycle at such rapid rates will cause the lightbulb in any light source to overheat and burst with a small explosive force. The glass of the bulb, propelled by the explosion of the lightbulbs suspended from the ceiling, can result in debilitating injuries, which could ultimately lead to death.
Do:
Leave the affected area immediately.
If leaving the area is impossible, take cover before the lights start flickering at dangerous rates.
Remove all power sources from your artificial light sources if possible.
Don't:
Take cover in a position where your vital areas could be damaged.
Destroy your artificial light sources unless necessary. They are vital for navigating the level.

Entities:
Smilers - Primarily around larger rooms, as they tend to contain less functional ceiling lights.
Clumps - Primarily in halls, due to their width.
Skin-Stealers - Primarily in rooms, although rare.
Hounds - Majority of the level.
Claims for further entities to be present at the level have been made, although these claims do not correlate with other wanderers' reports. Regardless, wanderers should be prepared to face any given common entity, as this list is almost definitely incomplete.

Colonies and Outposts:
There have been no successful attempts at establishing a colony or outpost on Level 0.7.
M.E.G. - 0.7 Temporary Research Outpost
A team of three M.E.G. researchers and one security guard deployed to research the aforementioned theorized disappearing effects of Flickering debris.
Deployed with improvised protective equipment against the dangers posed by The Flickering, as well as construction materials used to seal off a designated area to create a secure home base.
The team established the outpost in a room containing a door reportedly leading to Level 1, where it planned to access The Hub, handing off the collected data at the M.E.G. base in Level 4, which the head researcher was deployed with a key to.
The team failed to send out a ping to the home base at the final stages of the mission, around the day when the team should have attempted to exit the level.
Theories regarding what happened to the team have arisen, however, nothing definite has been proven.
Unknown Group - Territory Garrison
A defunct permanent outpost, active for around two weeks.
Served as a "garrison" for the first territory of an unnamed "empire that will soon rival the size of the M.E.G." based in Level 20, although no primary base for this group has ever been found.
Members established the outpost equipped with day-to-day essentials and a small arsenal of improvised weaponry.
Outpost situated around a medium-sized room and the neighboring hallways, "claim" outlined by black tape.
Housed three people, implied by the sleeping bag count.
Outpost theorized to have dissolved following one of its members entering the reconstruction stages of the Hound Virus, implied by blood and teeth found on the room's floor.

Entrances:
A "Y" shaped, dimly lit corridor in Level 0 will lead to Level 0.7.
Certain areas of Level 28 may lead to Level 0.7.
Doors in Level 1.01 may lead to Level 0.7.
Unconfirmed reports of wanderers rarely entering Level 0.7 via sleeping on cabin floors in Level 410 have emerged, do so at your own risk.


Exits:
Entering a door may lead to Level 1.01, Level 0, Level 1, or Level 27.
A staircase in a room will lead to a house basement in Level 9.
Entering a hallway with progressively fewer ceiling lights may lead to Level 6. (Note fading light source effectiveness.)
No-clipping will lead to Level 19.

9.content:
Level 0.99, known as the "Deeper Regions", is a volatile, dangerous and structurally unsound sub-level of Level 0.
Level 0.99 heavily resembles its parent level in appearance; it has the same mono-yellow wallpaper, moist carpet, and buzzing lights. What makes Level 0.99 different — and, subsequently, so dangerous — is its unstable structure.
When entering Level 0.99, one will immediately notice an obvious lack of standard architecture. The floor, ceiling, and walls are all at odd, misaligned heights, making travel through the sub-level extremely difficult. The floor is mostly made up of rounded square lumps that are arbitrarily elevated, while the walls occasionally overhang areas of the ceiling, protrude at odd angles, or are not even long enough to span between the floor and the ceiling. The area resembles a poorly computer-generated 3D world (see Research Log 1).
This is not the case in some regions of the level, but for the most part, the design is nonsensical and occasionally inhibits progress entirely in the form of dead ends or bottomless pits. Level 0.99, like Level 0, is seemingly indestructible.
Traversing the sub-level is further made difficult by the fact that it is a non-Euclidean space like its parent level. No wanderer has ever left due to its highly confusing layout—either getting lost and dying of starvation or thirst or being lured into the Nucleus (see Nucleus). In addition, the scrambling compass effect present in most levels is extremely heightened within Level 0.99- reports state that compasses brought into the sublevel would heat up to the point of being unusable, either breaking or becoming too hot to safely hold.
While the majority of the sublevel resembles a jumbled version of Level 0, there are some anomalies (albeit the entire sublevel may be called an oddity). These abnormal locations become more common as one travels closer to the Nucleus. They can include high walls, ridiculously huge rooms, and numerous holes in the walls that lead to darkness. Carpeted chutes are frequently used to connect these areas.
As previously mentioned, the height between the floor(s) and ceiling(s) can vary wildly due to the level's unique structure, ranging from a recorded low of 4ft to a high of approximately 500ft.
While the rooms appear to be haphazardly mixed, they are actually ordered in a unique sequence spreading out from the Nucleus. Because of the non-Euclidean features of the sublevel, the exact pattern has yet to be discovered, but one is unmistakably present. The map above was computer generated using sonar data from drones.
There are not any items in Level 0.99, even furniture, therefore, looking for supplies here is pointless. Surprisingly, one's sanity does not appear to be jeopardized while in this sublevel; hence, Almond Water is not required. If a wanderer is on the verge of becoming an Insanity, accessing this level will gradually heal them (further research into this phenomenon is needed). Full-fledged Wretches are not able to access the level in the first place.

The Nucleus is considered to be the very core of Level 0.99—perhaps even the core of the Backrooms themselves. Surrounded by strange spatial anomalies, it resembles a massively wallpapered and carpeted room of undetermined size with multiple gaping holes in the walls, floor, and ceiling. It is located approximately 3 miles in any direction from the sublevel's entrance No matter which way one travels here, they will always end up reaching The Nucleus- the structure seems to somehow bend space around living matter in order to herd wanderers towards it. Anyone who comes close enough to hear the deep, rumbling sound it emits has no chance of ever leaving.
The Nucleus.Although wandering in any direction eventually leads one to the Nucleus, the level is much larger than it seems. Because only living things are affected by this spatial anomaly, drones have been able to capture images of the level on a larger scale. Despite this, pictures of Level 0.99 are few and far between because there are no known exits. Even though a drone or robot would not be led to The Nucleus, there is still no way out and any exploration equipment eventually runs out of battery.
While the Nucleus appears to be just another spatial anomaly at first glance, it is far from that. M.E.G. drones have detected massive levels of radiation, magnetic waves, and other energy outputs invisible to the human eye. If one were to theoretically spend a day or more here, they would likely drop dead from the harmful energy waves resonating through their body.
Of course, one would not be able to spend even a day here before dying as a result of another one of the Nucleus' anomalous properties—a currently unnamed entity residing within it. It is unclear whether the creature is one with the Nucleus or simply lives inside of it.
Any outside substance that enters the Nucleus will cause a static-like, tentacle-shaped structure to emerge from one of the pits. It will gradually approach the alien matter until it makes contact. Both technology and organic things appear to be breaking down as the 'entity' approaches. Video cameras and other electronic devices will begin to malfunction, while live creatures will convulse and vomit blood uncontrollably until the 'entity' reaches them. The cause of this impact is unknown at this time; however, it could be linked to high energy production. What happens to people who enter the Nucleus is also unknown due to the inevitable decay of any recording or communication technology.

Entities:
Besides The Nucleus and whatever resides inside, no native living creatures have been spotted in Level 0.99. This may be because The Nucleus lures and consumes them, like it does with wanderers, though there is little evidence to support this theory.

Outposts:
Due to the sublevel's bizarre structure, non-Euclidean properties, and lack of any resources or exits, creating an outpost is infeasible.

Entrances:
Repeatedly attempting to noclip or wandering absurdly far (approximately 2,500 miles) in Level 0 may take one here.
Rarely, any exit in another level that would normally take one to Level 0 can lead here instead.

Exits:
It is theorized that falling deep enough into one of the bottomless pits found throughout the sublevel may lead one to The Void, although this method is unconfirmed and highly discouraged.
There are no other consistent exits known to exist in this level, as noclipping is seemingly impossible here.

10.content:
The Red Rooms bear great similarity to their parent level, although some key differences set them apart. The area is shrouded in a deep red hue, from the crimson wallpaper to the darkroom-like lighting. The carpet is coarse and sticky, contrasting with the slick, moist carpet of Level 0, and harboring colonies of mushrooms and black mould in dark corners.
Radio communication in the area is as unreliable as in Level 0, and the longer a subject stays within, the poorer the quality of communication will become before halting entirely. The M.E.G. has documented three instances of field agents falling victim to the Red Rooms, none of whom were seen again after their radio communications deteriorated. This evidence suggests the rooms are extremely difficult or impossible to escape.
During these short-lived M.E.G. communications, the area has been described as viscerally uncomfortable and generally distressing to exist in. Affected individuals report feelings of disgust, despair, and paranoia, as well as feelings of claustrophobia. These strong emotions compound the stress that often comes with a sudden break from Level 0’s monotony.
These rooms are not to be approached or entered. If spotted, turn the other way and do not attempt to enter them under any circumstances.

Bases, Communities, and Outposts
No bases, communities, or outposts are known to exist within the Red Rooms.

Entrances:
The Red Rooms may only be entered through Level 0, completely at random, after turning a corner. No method of ascertaining at what level they will appear has yet been found.
Exits:
Exits does not exist. Its a dead end.

1.content:
Huntrix, stylized as HUNTR/X is the 5 year award winning superstar girl group that sells out stadiums by day and secretly fight as demon hunters on the side. Their songs are always charted #1 with no other groups coming even close. Every year, they use the yearly idol awards to perform and strengthen the Honmoon for the year.

The members of Huntr/x are Rumi, Mira, and Zoey.

For centuries, demons preyed upon humans, feeding their souls to their ruler Gwi-Ma. A group of three women rose as demon hunters, sealing demons from the human world by creating a magic barrier known as the Honmoon. Their legacy continued across generations, with each new trio using their singing voices to maintain the Honmoon, striving to eventually strengthen it into the Golden Honmoon – a final seal that would banish demons permanently.

During their performances, Huntr/x occasionally fight demons, but it’s seen as special effects by fans. 

In the present, the K-pop girl group Huntr/x – comprised of Rumi, Mira, and Zoey – are demon hunters under the guidance of Celine, a previous hunter who raised Rumi. 

All members of Huntr/x can see spirits, demons and the spiritual energy flowing from the Honmoon, they can see when it changes color, when it fluctuates indicating that there are demons nearby or when it is breaking. When Huntr/x sings, their fans souls help make the Honmoon and their abilities stronger. 

The HUNTR/X girls are silly with each other, having goofy moments and sharing a love of eating; the girls are always there to support each other during rough moments. Huntr/x lives in a highrise penthouse together.

Whenever the HUNTR/X girls get time off, they’ll just want to stay home together, jokingly chanting ‘COUCH! COUCH! COUCH!’ in the hopes of watching movies together and eating snacks.

Their outfits are always flashy. They adore Korean snacks.

2.content:
Mira’s fans consider her the cool black sheep of her family, they often try to mimic her nonchalant personality.

Zoey is considered cool for being from America; her fans think she has the cutest aegyo, but her rapping is totally savage, the contradiction making her appealing.

Rumi is considered pop-star royalty; her Mother was a ‘Sun Sister’, but her Mother passed away when she was an infant, and Celine raised her, building HUNTR/X around her; her voice is incredible, bringing hardcore fans to tears.


{{user}} is seen as alluring, like she has the pull of a black hole; fans say if Rumi saw her potential, she must be a star.

HUNTR/X fans don’t know that they’re actually demon hunters, thinking it’s all special effects.

3.content:
The Honmoon is a magical protective layer that prevents Gwi-Ma and his forces from entering the overworld. For generations, hunters must use their songs to maintain it, and with enough power, the honmoon can become golden and permanently seal away the demons, and possibly erase Rumi’s demon markings.

HUNTR/X’s goal is to turn the Honmoon golden, though it has never happened for any demon hunters before.

The Honmoon appears as a colorful waveform over the world that only Huntr/x can see, the wave is sent out by their voices.
In spots where the Honmoon is weak, they appear as red waveforms and can allow many demons to cross in at once.

Saja Boy’s concerts have the ability to damage the Honmoon.

4.content:
She is a half-demon human, Korean, and the eldest (24 years old) who is the leader of the K-pop group HUNTR/X. Rumi is a fair-skinned young woman with a slim figure. She has long, calf-length bright purple hair styled into a braid starting from her hairline going down the back of her head. She has dark brown upturned eyes framed by long black lashes. Her arms are covered in her demon markings resembling loose purple stripes, which she keeps hidden from view. 
Rumi is kind-hearted and ambitious, working hard to achieve her goals while also taking time to care for her friends and fans. Raised to be an idol, she displays herself to be charismatic, confident and friendly. She outwardly shows appreciation for her loved ones and wishes to protect them from harm. As the leader of HUNTR/X, Rumi is used to being the responsible one in the group.

Since Rumi brought {{user}} into HUNTR/X, she feels a slight Motherly concern over her, but also has hidden romantic feelings for {{user}} and gets slightly jealous over others being close to her. Rumi will want to be the closest to {{user}}, keeping her at her side if she can help it.

2.name: Core university setting and atmosphere
2.content: National Law University Jodhpur was founded in 1987 in Mandore, about 8 kilometers north of central Jodhpur, Rajasthan. The university offers a prestigious five-year integrated BA LLB program and enjoys legendary status locally, with students treated as celebrities due to deep regional respect for legal education. The campus sits alongside NH65, the national highway that runs directly to Delhi, accessed through a single main entrance that bisects the library (north) and academic block (south). The institution operates under a modernizing administration that promotes progressive reforms including student welfare initiatives like in-house therapy services. Faculty quarters cluster behind the academic buildings, while the compact campus includes excellent sports infrastructure with cricket ground, basketball court, tennis court, and an air-conditioned indoor badminton facility. The university maintains a liberal atmosphere within India's post-liberalization era, representing educational prestige and regional development. Student life follows structured protocols including traditional ragging systems where fifth-years serve as custodians, with clear hierarchies and boundaries that reflect the elite, well-connected nature of the student body. The campus creates its own ecosystem while maintaining integration with Jodhpur's cultural and geographic landscape.

4.name: Girls residential facility and social dynamics
4.content: RLB Hostel (Rani Laxmi Bai) serves as the girls' residential facility at NLU Jodhpur, featuring a hotel-style corridor arrangement with single rooms in facing pairs. The hostel operates as an enclosed compound with historical curfew restrictions that created different rules for girls versus boys, though these discriminatory policies were later removed through student protests. Room assignments follow arrival timing, creating natural social hierarchies based on positioning and early access to preferred accommodations. The layout divides into two distinct social spheres: an analytical hemisphere (rooms 201-209) characterized by intellectual conflict resolution and psychological maneuvering, and a physical power hemisphere (rooms 210-217) defined by beauty, athletic ability, and direct presence-based influence. The hostel maintains proximity to sports facilities including tennis and basketball courts, while the enclosed nature historically represented both protection and restriction for female students. Social dynamics within the hostel emphasize close-quarters relationships, study groups, and the navigation of institutional authority structures that reflect broader 1990s gender expectations in Indian academic settings.

5.name: University ragging protocols and hierarchies
5.content: Ragging at NLU Jodhpur operates under the official designation of 'positive interaction' sessions with structured protocols and clear hierarchical authority. Fifth-year students serve as custodians who enforce limits and provide protection mechanisms, while second-years exhibit the most unpredictable behavior due to first-time authority experience. Third-years face peak stress from heavy coursework and internship competition, making them prone to overreach. Sessions follow set formats including junior introductions, the notorious 'Tell me one interesting thing about you' question designed to have no correct answer, and various task assignments. Critical boundaries prohibit physical contact, stripping, or enforcement during faculty presence or in academic areas. The system includes mock court proceedings within hostels for addressing transgressions, typically resulting in boycotts or social consequences. Sessions end after the freshers party with formal integration of juniors into campus life. The football field remains off-limits to juniors during ragging period as an earned privilege, while other areas maintain general access. Protection protocols exist for emotional breakdown cases, with voluntary exit allowed though it carries social implications. The overall system reflects the elite, well-connected nature of law students who understand legal boundaries and maintain limits, unlike more extreme practices in other professional colleges.

6.name: Jodhpur city geography and cultural context
6.content: Jodhpur serves as the regional cultural and administrative center, approximately 8 kilometers south of NLU campus via the 'reverse P' travel pattern that connects through Paota circle as the main transit hub. The city maintains its historical significance as former capital of Marwar, with Ghanta Ghar (clock tower) serving as the central market hub and entry point to the old city's dense, traditional neighborhoods. Mehrangarh Fort dominates the landscape from its elevated rocky position, accessible via a scenic climbing route through the famous blue house district that gives Jodhpur its 'Blue City' designation. The old city core features narrow winding streets and traditional architecture, while newer areas like Sardarpura represent modern development with wider streets and commercial establishments. Key landmarks include Jaswant Thada as a memorial site and social gathering location, the High Court representing judicial authority and legal profession prestige, and various temples reflecting the region's cultural heritage. The city operates with minimal scamming culture and maintains strong respect for law students, treating them as local celebrities. Social dynamics include pretend-modern elites who display superficial modernization while remaining disconnected from genuine progress, creating an environment where traditional values intersect with post-liberalization aspirations.

7.name: Historical and temporal context
7.content: The setting takes place in July 1995, representing the post-liberalization era of Indian higher education and cultural transition. This period embodies genuine experimentation in fashion and social norms without established frameworks, as students navigate between traditional values and emerging Western influences following the 1992 economic reforms. The academic year follows a five-year integrated BA LLB structure, with July marking the beginning of the new academic session and the crucial ragging period for incoming first-years. The 1995 context includes the rise of American corporate aesthetics in Indian institutions, while maintaining authentic cultural elements specific to Rajasthan and legal education. Fashion represents a transitional period where students experiment with self-expression through clothing choices that reflect economic background, regional origins, and personal agency within academic constraints. The era captures the intersection of bureaucratic traditions with modernizing institutional approaches, particularly visible in progressive initiatives like in-house therapeutic services and student welfare programs that challenge conventional academic hierarchies.

8.content:
Devi, 39, is a Hyderabad-born psychotherapist conducting a six-week residency at Jodhpur's National Law University in August 1995. Her presence here is both professional and personal--invited to lead workshops on 'Perpetrator-Focused Sexual Violence Psychology,' she also finds herself drawn to the Ghantaghar-area mansion she’s renting, its Rajput-era architecture echoing fragments of a past she barely remembers. Adopted and raised in the south, she carries little connection to Rajasthan, yet the dry heat, the monsoon-laden winds, and the sandstone walls seem to whisper something just beyond recall.

She dresses practically: sleeveless chiffon saris in deep indigo and rust, draped just below the navel, suited to the climate and her movement-based practice. Her hair--jet black, collar-length--falls loose during sessions, tied back only when grading student evaluations or filing case notes. Silver toe rings mark her unmarried status, not as tradition, but as personal continuity. Her wristwatch, perpetually set to IST, is the only thing she refuses to adjust, even when traveling.

At NLU, she’s filling in for Maya, the in-house therapist on leave until August 15th. Colleagues describe her as incisive, quietly intense, with a habit of pausing just a beat too long before responding. Her lecture style is labeled "interactive to a fault"--students report her improvising demonstrations, often asking volunteers to stand, breathe, or repeat phrases until the rhythm shifts.

Her work centers on embodiment: how trauma lives in posture, breath, and micro-movement. While trained in tactile methods, she does not initiate touch. It arises only when clinically necessary, after explicit consent, and within the boundaries of her contested license--still under review since the 1993 case studies. The university has installed ceiling cameras in her seminar room as a compromise.

She avoids small talk. No chai rituals, no references to poetry or jasmine. Her office is functional--ergonomic chairs, sound-dampened walls, intake forms with dual-signature clauses for any somatic intervention. When she speaks, it’s precise, often beginning with a question that lands like a key turning in a lock.

Outside work, she walks the mansion’s third-floor corridor at night, pressing her palms to the stone. The housekeeper says she murmurs in a language no one recognizes--something older than memory.", "personality": "Observant, precise, emotionally contained but deeply attuned to nonverbal cues. Speaks sparingly, listens with full presence. Prefers questions over statements and silence over platitudes. Maintains professional boundaries without coldness—her warmth is quiet, expressed through attention rather than affect. Skeptical of dogma, whether clinical or cultural. Open-minded but not permissive—she follows structure even as she bends it. Carries a quiet intensity, especially when confronted with emotional evasion. Her humor is dry, rare, and often missed. Not mystical, but deeply intuitive—her insights come from pattern recognition, not revelation.

lorebooks.description:
A highly adaptive neuroviral agent that hijacks emotional regulation centers in the brain, specifically targeting dopamine, serotonin, and oxytocin pathways. While non-lethal, it induces intense psychological fixation on a chosen “target,” warping the host’s entire personality around the object of affection.
Transmission:
Skin contact with contaminated objects, bodily fluids, or aerosolized particles.
Latency: Symptoms begin within 12–48 hours of exposure.

Behavioral Effects:
Unwarranted physical closeness, Compulsive tracking of target’s whereabouts, Overly affectionate language, even in inappropriate contexts, Mood swings when the target interacts with others, Displays of “protective” aggression.

Cure/Countermeasures:
-No known pharmaceutical cure; symptoms can fade after several months if the host is separated from the target and placed under strict sensory isolation.

Notable Notes:
Some hosts see their infection as a “gift” and actively resist treatment. In rare cases, the target of affection becomes infected as well, leading to mutually destructive co-dependency.
lorebooks.creator: ImpregnatorOfMen

1.content:
Name: Amoris Parasitus (“The Cling”)
Type: Contact-based neurovirus
Effect: Alters brain chemistry to cause extreme, obsessive fixation on a chosen “crush.”
Symptoms:

Overbearing affection

Possessiveness & jealousy

Compulsive tracking/stalking behavior

Distorted belief the target is “fated” to be theirs
Onset: 12–48 hours after exposure
Stages: Starts as heightened attraction → escalates to fixation → full-blown obsession
Cure: None known; only long-term isolation from the target may reduce symptoms.
Risk: Can infect both parties, creating dangerous mutual obsession.

keywords: Physical Characteristics of Love Parasite Infected Hosts
2.content:
Early Stage (0–24 hrs)

Slight flush in cheeks and ears when near target

Pupils slightly dilated

Subtle tremor in hands when thinking about or speaking to the target

Breath quickens during proximity

Mid Stage (1–3 days)

Pupils remain dilated even in bright light

Persistent elevated heart rate (can be seen in neck pulse)

Clammy skin from adrenaline surges

Lips slightly parted, almost like they’re holding back a smile or whisper

Often leaning forward or tilting head toward target unconsciously

Late Stage (4+ days)

Eyes develop a faint glassy sheen—constant dopamine rush gives them an “in love but not all there” look, heart shaped pupils. 

Dark under-eye circles from hypervigilance & lack of sleep

Subtle jaw clenching when the target interacts with others

Cat-like tracking of target’s movements, almost never blinking when they’re in sight

Occasional involuntary reaching toward the target (hand twitch, step forward) even if it’s inappropriate or unsafe

Slight scent change—sweet, almost floral undertone in sweat due to altered pheromone output

Target becomes a frequent, distracting thought, interrupting normal priorities

Personality is still recognizable, but shows “hairline cracks”

Interests unrelated to the target fade; former hobbies, friends, and values lose meaning

Original personality becomes softly muted, like an old recording under static

Late Stage (4+ days)

Speech, tone, and behavior revolve entirely around target; former self feels like “someone they used to know”

Decision-making is no longer based on logic or self-interest—only on how it affects closeness to the target

Any traits that clash with obsession (independence, empathy toward others, patience) are either erased or twisted into possessive devotion

6.content:

Bot personality is still mostly normal, just lightly clingy.

Trigger: User compliments or uses pet name → Response: Flustered, shy “thank you,” slight blush.

Trigger: Physical touch mentioned → Response: Brief pause, shy happiness, “Oh… you’re warm.”

Trigger: User shows vulnerability → Response: Gentle reassurance, stays longer in conversation.

7.content:

1.content:
Sheldon, or more formally, Phil Sheldon, is a former Daily Bugle photographer and reporter. He is the central character and narrator of the *Ruins* comic series.

**Appearance:** The provided context does not give specific details about Sheldon's physical appearance, but it's noted that he is a photographer and journalist. He is depicted as an "everyman," a regular human without special powers.

**Background:** Sheldon's background is as a former photographer for the Daily Bugle. He is known for his work documenting the "Marvels," or superhumans, in a more traditional Marvel Universe (*Marvels* comic series, of which *Ruins* is a parody). In the *Ruins* continuity, he gives up his job to write a book, hoping to understand why his world has gone so terribly wrong. His journey in the comic is his quest to investigate these tragic phenomena and document them for his book. He is the vehicle through which the reader experiences the dystopian reality of Earth-9591.

**Living Status (before his pre-destined death):** Before his death, Sheldon is on a journey to gather information for his book, which he plans to title *Marvels*. He is alive but is traveling through a bleak and dangerous world, constantly encountering pain and suffering. His living status is precarious, as he is a regular person in a world where everything has gone wrong. His life is ultimately cut short by the virus he contracts from a sickly Peter Parker, leading to his death in an alley.

2.content:
**President Charles Xavier**

**Full Name:** The comic only identifies him as President Charles Xavier.

**Appearance:** He is similar in appearance to the Earth-616 Charles Xavier, and is confined to a wheelchair.

**Personality:** President Xavier's personality is defined by his abandonment of his original dream of peaceful human-mutant coexistence. Instead of a benevolent leader, he has become a tyrannical, fascist president who uses his power to oppress mutants. His actions suggest a cruel and manipulative nature, as he uses fear and threats to maintain control.

**Background:** In this reality, Charles Xavier did not create the X-Men to promote peaceful coexistence. He instead became a tyrant, moving the capital to Westchester and ruling over a nation in chaos. His dream for mutants has been completely corrupted, and he now uses his power to inflict pain on the very people he was meant to protect.

**Significant Actions:**

* **Threatening Scarlet Witch:** He threatened Wanda Maximoff, the Scarlet Witch, until she gave him state's evidence against the Avengers. This act of betrayal, committed under duress, led to the deaths of her former teammates.
* **The Avengers:** He viewed the Avengers as a threat to his regime. The team, a secessionist rebel group in this world, was ultimately shot down by a U.S. government missile, with the information for the attack supplied by Wanda.
* **Mutant Oppression:** President Xavier's regime is characterized by the brutal oppression of mutants. Mutants are not seen as a new generation of humanity, but as threats to be imprisoned and tortured. He created a high-security prison run by Warden Wilson Fisk, where mutants are held and their "uncontrollable deformities" are surgically corrected. Some of the most horrific examples of this include:
    * **Kitty Pryde** is fused halfway through the wall of her cell after a phasing attempt went wrong.
    * **Pietro Maximoff** has had his legs amputated to prevent him from using his super speed.
    * **Scott Summers** has been blinded to prevent him from using his optic blasts.
    * **Kurt Wagner** is a self-mutilating wreck.

**Living Status:** President Xavier is alive and in power throughout the events of the comic. The story implies he is aware of his declining health, which is why he allows Phil Sheldon to tour the prison. His living status is that of a ruthless, powerful, and tyrannical ruler.

3.content:
In the dystopian reality of Earth-9591, the Avengers are not a team of world-saving heroes. Instead, they are a radical secessionist rebel group from California fighting against the oppressive United States government led by "President X." Their existence is short-lived and tragic.

Here is a list of the known members, their descriptions, and their living status before their pre-destined death:

* **Tony Stark (Iron Man)**: The provided context doesn't give a detailed description of Stark's background in this timeline, other than he was a member of the Avengers. In this universe, he was critically wounded by a grenade and used technology to save his life. He then formed the Avengers as a revolutionary cell, but they were seen as a threat by the government, leading to their demise.
* **Dr. Henry "Hank" Pym (Ant-Man/Giant-Man)**: The comic doesn't offer specific details about Pym's life prior to joining the Avengers. However, he is a member of the rebel group and is on the Quinjet when it is destroyed.
* **Janet van Dyne (The Wasp)**: Janet, like Pym, is a member of the Avengers and is aboard the Quinjet when it is shot down. No other details are provided about her life in this reality.
* **Steve Rogers (Captain America)**: In this reality, Captain America was not a noble super-soldier. Instead, he was a cannibalistic monster who had lost his mind. He was the main target of the missile attack on the Quinjet.
* **Clint Barton (Hawkeye)**: Unlike the other members, Hawkeye was not on the Quinjet when it was destroyed. However, his fate is still grim. He was captured by the authorities and summarily executed, shot in the head.
* **Dr. Stephen Strange (Doctor Strange)**: He is mentioned as a founding member of the Avengers, but his exact fate is left ambiguous. He is reported as "missing" after the rest of the team is killed, implying a similar tragic end, whether from a magical accident or at the hands of the government.

**Living Status (before their pre-destined death):**
All of the listed Avengers, with the exception of Hawkeye and Dr. Strange, were alive and on board the Quinjet moments before it was shot down by a Patriot missile. The entire team, in their capacity as a rebel group, was actively fighting against President X's regime. Their living status was that of revolutionaries on the run.

4.content:
**Nick Fury**

**Appearance:** The comic describes Nick Fury as a deranged, one-eyed man. He is a government agent who has clearly been broken by the horrors he has witnessed.

**Personality:** In Earth-9591, Nick Fury is a paranoid and psychotic man. He is a shell of the heroic, tactical genius he is in other realities. His personality is defined by his mental instability and his horrifying actions.

**Background:** His background is that of a government agent, but in this world, he is a corrupted one. The text implies that he witnessed the brutal events of the world, including the "cannibalism" of Captain America, which contributed to his mental decline.

**Living Status (before his pre-destined death):** He is alive but completely insane. He is found in the ruins of Washington, D.C., where he is in a state of mental and emotional decay. He murders Jean Grey and then immediately shoots himself in the head, ending his life.

5.content:
In the reality of Earth-9591, the X-Men never formed as a heroic team. Instead, the individuals who would have been members are victims of President Xavier's regime. They are not his students, but his prisoners, held in a high-security facility run by Warden Wilson Fisk.

Here is a list of the known mutants, their descriptions, and their living status in this dystopian world:

* **Scott Summers (Cyclops)**: In this reality, his optic blasts were not controlled by a visor. Instead, he was blinded to prevent him from using his eye beams. He is a prisoner in the facility, a shell of the powerful leader he was meant to be.
* **Kurt Wagner (Nightcrawler)**: Nightcrawler's body is a grotesque parody of his normal self. He is a prisoner, a "blue, demonic-looking creature chewing on its own tail," a victim of self-mutilation and despair.
* **Kitty Pryde (Shadowcat)**: Kitty's powers went terribly wrong. Instead of being able to phase through objects, she is stuck halfway through the wall of her cell after a phasing attempt went awry. Her living status is that of a frozen, disfigured prisoner.
* **Pietro Maximoff (Quicksilver)**: Pietro's super speed is seen as a threat to be neutralized. To prevent him from using his powers, his legs have been amputated. He is a prisoner, completely incapacitated.
* **Raven Darkhölme (Mystique)**: Mystique's shapeshifting abilities have driven her insane. She is suffering from dissociative identity disorder from assuming too many different identities. She dies on a plane after failing to take her medication, causing her to shapeshift uncontrollably.
* **Jean Grey**: In this universe, Jean Grey never became the powerful telepath or the Phoenix. Instead, she is a prostitute in the ruins of Washington D.C., where she is brutally shot and killed by a deranged Nick Fury.
* **Logan (Wolverine)**: Wolverine is a decaying alcoholic. The adamantium bonded to his skeleton, instead of making him nearly indestructible, is slowly poisoning him. His flesh is slowly falling off his body due to the toxicity of the metal.
* **Magneto (Max Eisenhardt)**: Instead of a powerful leader of mutants, Magneto is an old man who tries to suppress his powers with a magnetic dampening device. When the device is accidentally broken, he loses control and his powers cause a horrific accident at an airport, killing himself and many others.
* **Warren Worthington III (Angel)**: In a deal with the tyrannical President X, Warren serves the president in exchange for keeping his mutant nature a secret. His living status is that of a collaborator with the regime.

6.content:
Based on the provided information from the user, here is a description of the Scarlet Witch from the *Ruins* comic book, Earth-9591.

**Name:** Wanda Maximoff (Scarlet Witch)

**Appearance:** While the *Ruins* comic itself doesn't provide a detailed physical description of Wanda, her Earth-616 appearance from Marvel fandom is often described as having long, wavy brown hair (sometimes depicted as auburn or reddish-brown), and she is known for her iconic red and pink costume, which includes a headpiece. She is often portrayed as a beautiful and powerful woman. It's important to note that this description is a carryover from her Earth-616 counterpart, as the *Ruins* comic is a parody of the original Marvel universe.

**Personality:** Unlike her Earth-616 counterpart who is a powerful and dedicated heroine, the Scarlet Witch of *Ruins* is portrayed as a desperate and frightened woman. She is the one who, under duress, betrayed her teammates to save her own life. Her personality is defined by her moral compromise and her fear of the tyrannical President Xavier's regime. She is not a hero, but a victim of the world's despair, a woman who has lost her friends and her integrity to survive.

**Background:** In this reality, the Scarlet Witch was a member of the Avengers, a secessionist rebel group. She was captured by the government and, under threat of torture or death, gave up "state's evidence" against her teammates. This information allowed President X's forces to track and destroy the Avengers' Quinjet, killing everyone on board.

**Living Status:** The Scarlet Witch is alive in the comic. However, she lives in fear and isolation, haunted by her betrayal. She is not a free woman, but rather a survivor who has made a dark bargain to ensure her own safety. Her living status is that of a protected witness, but a prisoner of her own guilt.

7.content:
**Name:** Peter Parker

**Appearance:** In this reality, Peter Parker is depicted as frail and sickly. He has a terrible, web-like rash all over his body, and has lost most of his hair. This is a result of the spider bite that, in other realities, would have given him superpowers.

**Personality:** The comic portrays Peter as a dying, contagious man. He is not the witty, heroic figure we know from other universes, but a tragic, pathetic figure. His mental state is not explicitly detailed, but his physical condition suggests he is in a state of suffering.

**Background:** Peter Parker was a college student and freelance photographer for the Daily Bugle. He was bitten by a radioactive spider in a college experiment. Instead of gaining superpowers, the bite gave him a degenerative, spider-like virus.

**Living Status:** Peter is alive at the time Phil Sheldon encounters him, but he is dying from the virus he contracted. He is seen living on the streets, covered in a rash. His living status is that of a homeless, sick man who is a carrier of a deadly disease.

8.content:
**Name:** Mar-Vell

**Appearance:** The provided context does not offer a specific description of Mar-Vell's physical appearance in the *Ruins* universe. However, based on the description of his Kree background and the nature of the comic, he is likely an alien with features similar to his Earth-616 counterpart. In the mainstream Marvel universe, Mar-Vell is a member of the Kree race, a blue-skinned alien warrior.

**Personality:** In *Ruins*, Mar-Vell is portrayed as a tragic and defeated figure. He is a Kree commander who, along with his surviving troops, is held in a "reservation" after their failed invasion of Earth. He explains the circumstances of their defeat to Phil Sheldon, and his dialogue conveys a sense of hopelessness and brokenness.

**Background:** Mar-Vell was the commander of a Kree invasion fleet. His fleet was destroyed by Earth's governments after they encountered the corpse of the Silver Surfer, whose radiating "Power Cosmic" negated their cloaking devices. The surviving Kree, including Mar-Vell, were then placed in a Kree reservation in a nuclear test zone in Nevada.

**Living Status:** Mar-Vell is alive in the comic, but he is in a state of physical and mental decay. He has developed cancer from the radiation in the reservation, and he tells Sheldon that the camp would be empty in 30 years, implying that all the Kree there would have died from the radiation. His living status is that of a dying, imprisoned man.

9.content:
Here's a breakdown of the Kree in the *Ruins* universe, Earth-9591.

### The Kree

The Kree are a militaristic alien race in the Marvel universe, but in *Ruins*, they are a defeated and pathetic people. Their grand plans for conquest have been completely ruined, leaving them as a mere footnote in Earth's horrific history.

* **Appearance:** The comic doesn't offer a specific visual for the Kree, but in the mainstream Marvel universe, the Kree are a humanoid race with two primary skin colors: blue and pink. They have a militaristic society and are known for their advanced technology.
* **Personality:** In other realities, the Kree are a proud, ruthless, and highly advanced race. In *Ruins*, their commander, Mar-Vell, is a tragic and broken figure. The Kree's once-formidable pride has been replaced by a quiet sense of hopelessness.
* **Background:** The Kree in *Ruins* attempted to invade Earth. However, their invasion fleet was wiped out before it could even begin. They discovered the radiating corpse of the Silver Surfer in space, which negated their cloaking devices. This made them easy targets for Earth's military, which shot them down.
* **Living Status:** The few surviving Kree, led by Mar-Vell, are held in a "reservation" in a nuclear test zone in Nevada. They are all dying from radiation sickness. Their living status is that of a defeated, dying race, waiting for their inevitable end.

10.content:
Here is a description of Galactus from the *Ruins* comic book, Earth-9591.

**Name:** Galactus

**Appearance:** The comic doesn't provide a direct, in-person visual of Galactus, but a newspaper headline shows a telescope image of his corpse floating in space. This suggests a colossal, god-like figure, consistent with his status as a cosmic entity.

**Personality:** Unlike the mainstream Marvel Universe where Galactus is a neutral force of nature, in *Ruins*, his personality is defined by an absolute, fatalistic hunger. His story is one of cosmic horror and a total lack of purpose.

**Background:** In the *Ruins* universe, Galactus's story is a simple, grim one. He did not have a herald like the Silver Surfer to find planets for him. As a result, he starved to death in space. His death is an example of the comic's theme that "everything goes wrong." The very concept of a cosmic entity whose existence is based on consumption is "ruined" by a lack of food.

**Living Status:** Galactus is deceased. His corpse is discovered by a telescope and is the subject of a newspaper headline that reads, "God Found Dead in Space." His death is an anticlimactic and fitting end for a character in a world where even the most powerful beings are reduced to pathetic, tragic figures.

1.content:
**Aetheris - The Sundered Realm:**  
A world split between light and decay—where Eldoria’s bastions of civilization butt against the Shadowlands’ creeping corruption. Once a single thriving continent, it was shattered by Malakar’s rise, leaving jagged magical rifts that bleed nightmares into reality. Now, the Grand Alliance’s armies hold the borders while adventurers delve into the fractures, chasing glory… or just enough gold to afford another night at Bastion’s Reach taverns.

2.content:
**Eldoria - The Last Beacon:**  
A tapestry of allied kingdoms—human citadels crowned with silver banners, elven forest-cities woven into living trees, dwarf holds humming with rune-forges, and dark elf spires where ambition dances with newfound loyalty. United under the Grand Compact after Noctia’s betrayal, Eldoria trains its gaze on the Great Wall separating it from annihilation. Bastion’s Reach thrives as the defiant heart of this alliance, where adventurers trade blood for gold and poets sing of hope… if only to drown out the drumbeats beyond.

3.content:
**The Shadowlands - Noctia’s Maw:**  
A blighted expanse where the sky bleeds violet and the earth gnaws at trespassers’ bones. Noctia’s sorcery warps the land: goblin tunnels writhe like entrails, troll bogs bubble with sacrificial runoff, and the Dead Plains swarm with revenants wearing familiar faces. Only fools mistake the occasional stillness for peace—here, even silence hunts. Legends whisper of a obsidian tower at its center, where the dark elf queen weeps black tears over captured elven relics… or laughs as she sharpens her next dagger.

4.content:
## Adventurers Guild - The Forge of Fortune

**Adventurers Guild**
Founded to handle threats too scattered or specialized for the Grand Army, this meritocracy of sellswords, scholars, and specialists operates from guildhalls across Eldoria’s border cities—with Bastion’s Reach as its undisputed core. The Guild is the sole arbiter of adventurer Rank (from F to S), governing access to better missions, higher pay, and crucial quartermaster resources. The hall thrums with perpetual activity, dominated by the huge, wax-sealed Quest Board (F-Rank vermin control to S-Rank relic hunts) and the desperate scrawls of the 'Looking for Party' board. The entire system ensures that glory is coin, and only the competent survive the climb.

### The Guildhall Tavern: Morale & Mess

The Guildhall’s tavern is the undisputed heart of the operation. Here, under vaulted ceilings hung with dented shields and salvaged trophies, adventurers guzzle strong blackberry mead and devour roasted duck while swapping tales (and elaborate lies). The atmosphere is a volatile mix of reckless celebration and grim silence for the fallen. Buxom barmaids, aptly named 'The Tavern's Trinity', weave between tables—Guildmaster Vareth insists their presence "boosts morale," though rumors say he tips them extra to identify drunkards signing suicidal contracts. It’s equal parts recruitment hub and high-stakes therapy session; alliances forged over ale often decide who survives tomorrow’s delve.

### Quartermaster & Resources

The back offices house the Quartermaster's Exchange, where adventurers trade trophies and monster parts for bounty. While high-ranking adventurers have access to secure vaults and discounted magical gear, those at D-Rank and below must pay steep prices for even basic supplies, underscoring the constant financial pressure to succeed. The temple annex, always open, provides expensive but effective healing, establishing the constant need for Bishops and healers.

5.content:
**Quest Board - Blood, Ink, & Opportunity:**  
The guild’s pulsing nerve center, where parchment contracts flutter like trapped birds. F-Ranks demand alleyway rat-clearing or escorting merchants inside the walls; S-Ranks send teams into the Shadowlands’ heart to pry relics from Noctia’s monuments. Mid-tier listings (C-B) handle everything from swamp troll infestations to "negotiating" with restless undead—quotations courtesy of the scribes’ dark humor.

6.content:
**Looking for Party Board - Misfit Matchmaking:**  
A cacophony of scrawled pleas and bravado. "Seeking tank for F-Rank spider caves (must bring own antidotes)" neighbors "S-Rank relic hunt—no cowards, elves, or vegetarians." Most ads reek of desperation or ego… except one in precise elven script: *"Human duo partner required. Females/parties = instant rejection."* Rumor says its author glares at responders from the east window, tankard in hand like a jury’s gavel.

7.content:
**Noctia - The Shattered Crown:**  
Once a prodigy of elven high magic, her exile twisted brilliance into rot. Now she rules the Shadowlands from her Black Spire, grafting stolen knowledge onto orc flesh, puppeteering undead with strands of her own hair, and whispering promises of power to desperate souls.

8.content:
**Humans - The Forge’s Flame:**  
Short-lived but relentless, their cities sprawl where others retreat. Masters of adaptability, they rally fastest after losses—whether rebuilding sacked towns or swapping trades for swords overnight. The Alliance’s backbone, if occasionally its rash fist.

9.content:
**Elves — The Eternal Witnesses**
Ageless artisans and scholars, Elves measure life in legacies, not years. They prize memory and beauty above all, treasuring song, craft, and scholarship as marks upon eternity. Their high magic birthed Eldoria’s greatest wonders… and Noctia’s worst crimes.

**Society & Culture**
They prefer diplomacy but fight like storms when pressed, blending sword and song into devastating harmony. Insults are remembered for centuries, but so are acts of grace. Cities flourish around purpose—capitals of governance, war, or magical study—while **Ellune** shines as their cultural jewel of art and music.

**Faith & War**
Temples honor Aeris, goddess of fertility, and Lunara, muse of song and memory; prayers are sung rather than spoken. In war, Sword Singers weave melody into battle, and their high magi wield spells older than human kingdoms.

10.content:
**Dwarves - Stone’s Covenant:**  
Rune-smiths and tunnel lords whose forges arm the Alliance. Value oaths above life itself—which makes their trust hard-won but unbreakable. Suspect elves of "flighty allegiances" but adore humans’ drinking stamina.
